Draught at Oliver Twist, Stockholm. Golden color, white head. Malty, fruity aroma with some alcohol. Honey and fruits in aroma, and again alcohol. Not a favorite for me.

(Draught at Stockholm Beer Festival, 2 Oct 2010) Golden yellow colour with frothy, white head. Fruity, slightly malty nose with citrus, apricots and honey. Malty, fruity taste with notes of apricots, citrus, tropical fruit, honey and grassy hops in the finish. Slightly more than medium body, quite sweet, with a generous grassy bitterness. Far too sweet and fruity for a pilsener, but still quite nice.

Flight sample at Morimoto. Pours a hazy light yellow, with a very thin white head. Aroma of fresh hay, honey, wheat, soap suds, and West Coast hops. Medium to light bodied with a thin, slightly tart palate. Finishes dry and with citrus hints. Decent.

Bottle. Pours hazy orange with white head. Aromas are of sweet malts, spice, resin and spruce. This is a very malt-driven pilsner, with sweet malt dominating the front of the palate. This is balanced by a bold bitterness that lingers nicely. I really enjoyed this beer. The only negative is the hefty price tag.
Bottle at SBWF 2010. It poured a hazy yellow liquid with a small white head. Fruity flavour but also very alcoholic. Not one of the better Imperial Pilsners Ive tried.
Pale pour in a tasting glass with a short lived and slight head. Didnt pick up any imperial intensity as the flavor just fell off after taking in, mouthfeel was not there.

Bottle. Pours hazy orange with about a one inch foamy head. Head recedes but stays all the way. Nose of grapefruit hops, lots of malts. Some notes of straw and spices. Taste is similar to aromas. Lots of hops up front, balanced well by plenty of malt. Some spice and a bit of alcohol. Long dry bitter aftertaste. Full bodied brew.

Heavy malting and a touch of fruitness in aroma,tangy hops coming through, looks a little darker in the pilsner glass ,beautiful ascent of carbonation,heavier malting comes through in flavor, slightly sweet aftertaste, A sipping pilsner

Swing top ceramic bottle. Hazy orange sparce head. Big orange zest aroma with some bread & buscuit malt. Really chuncky pils? thats quite carbonated and chewy. Rice & malt character then dry bitterness and alcohol in the background. Very good & unique beer.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2010 on tap at the Pumphouse in Darling Harbour. Poured into Rogue Chalices. Pours a cloudy yellow, with a light white head. Aroma is quite floral, and taste is grain, citrus and honey. finish is a bit harsh with a moderate alcohol flavour.
Draft.  Pours a slightly cloudy golden yellow color with a large white head.  Very floral on the nose.  Decent flavor but a little sour.  Slightly dry and mouthfeel.  The 8.8 % is fairly noticeable.

750ml bottle from Winooski Bev shared with Thierry.
Appearance : Hazy yellow with a small creamy head.

Aroma : Crisp biscuits malt with herbal and floral crisp hops. Some fruits. Nice maltiness.

Taste : Very malty with crisp herbal hops. Finish is very herbal, a bit spicy and a bit warm. Quite bitter. Finish feels a little bit harsh. Faint carbonation. Not much alcohol.

Overall : Nice brew ! Very herbal and floral. I like the hops on this beer. Very enjoyable but for the price, it need to be even better for me to buy again.

Draught. Firstly, the goblet glass is seriously cool. The beer poured a golden straw. Small head which stuck around forever. Tones of lacing. Serious eye-candy. Fresh, malty, citrus aroma.  Taste was a huge punch of hops at first but then calmed by a nice malt finish. I found it dry and bitter. Awesome. Beautifully smooth. Lively carbornation. 8.8%? Would never had known.

Light and hazy, big head.  Pineapple really dominates the aroma - youd think there was pineapple juice in it.  Taste is fairly bitter and sweet - a thick feel to it.  Then the finish is a bit of bitter pineapple.  A good beer with more taste to it than I was expecting.

1 pt. 10 oz. ceramic bottle. Expensive.  Pours golden, slightly hazy with decent white head.  Hoppy aroma.  Bitter, strong and hoppy tasting.  Seemed more like an IPA than a pilsner.  Not sure if I will try again.

This beer pours nice and golden yellow, almost orange hued, with a big sudsie head.  A constant stream of bubbles in side the glass make me think this is a highly carbonated beer.  The aroma is nice and hoppy with some sweet floral/perfumy notes.  The beer is stronger than the aroma leads you expect, but the flavors are true to the aroma, the bitterness is eye opening.   The malts are big and bold, matching up very nicely with the big hop.  The finish is surprisingly sharp, but there lingers a bit of flowers
750ml bottle shared by Mike and Janet. Rating #543. Straw gold with a white head. Light bread aroma. Crisp clean flavor and quite tasty. (1218)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: I like the idea of the heavier malt profile in a pilsner, but I wouldnt buy this beer again and Ill leave it at that.
Pours hazy reddish gold with a thin white head and a fruity aroma. There is a hearty caramel malt flavor with a nice hop bitterness,  A very good brew.

07/2007: Quick notes on this beer: 

Cloudy dark gold color....thick head ... Hazy.... not your typical pilsner color. 

All malt smell ... nice sweet pilsner/lager smell, just amplified. 

Taste has a surprising number of hops, but nice sweet flowery malt is there too. Its still a pils, just better. Has a pretty powerful alcoholic kick. 

The feel is thick and creamy. Its a tad bubbly. Very dry. Leaves a malty film which isnt entirely welcome. Its not a bad beer. Its pretty got-damn strong for a pils, thats for sure. One and thats about all I can do.

Rogue Ales--Oregon Brewing Company--Morimoto Signature Imperial Pilsner--White Ceramic Stoneware Bottle.

2004 Black  22 oz. Release.  8.75% ABV--78 IBUs.  (4.5 / 5.0)  Lacy foamy head.  Cloudy rich golden orange color.  Smooth mild dry hopped front.  Crisp rich creamy mild sweet dry butterscotch Pilsner malty body.  Rich hot tangy hoppy mild citrus end.  Big & Smooth.  Sampled 7/21/2004.

2005 26 oz. Release. 8.80% ABV--74 IBUs.  (4.75 / 5.0)  Rich white head.  Clear thin bright straw gold color.  Huge spicy floral Saaz hop front.  Creamy rich crisp Pils malty body.  Clean hoppy balanced mild spice citrus end.  Wow hops and crisp Pils flavor.  Dangerously smooth.  Sampled 12/22/2005.

2007 26 oz. Release.  8.80% ABV--74 IBUs.  (4.5 / 5.0)  Tight lacy white head.  Cloudy bright lemon gold color.  Crisp aromatic mellow Sterling hop front.  Rich tangy dry sweet mellow butter caramel malty body.  Tangy clean Lager smooth balanced hop spice end.  Sampled 5/4/2007.
From a bottle poured a straw color with a small amount of head.  Nice light hoppy flavor with lingering finish.
On tap - really lovely dusty dried grass and malt body. Very clean and fresh.

Pours golden with a slight haze. Off white head with good retention. Aroma is somewhat musty, with honeyish malt and lemony hops. 
Syrupy mouthfeel, great full body. A fairly strong honey sweetness is fast offset by intense lemony hops. Hops dominate the finish. Its honey/lemon drink in a beer! Cant believe this is lager yeast - best lager Ive had yet!
obviously awesome packaging. sweet bready malty and spicy hop aroma. same sweet flavour with a pappery hoppiness. this is a big beer that gets a bit cloying, a little cripser and it would be awesome.

Slightly hazy, golden colour. Big aroma of malt and some spicy hops to. Big malt driven flavour but well balanced, the alcohol is well masked and doesnt come through to strongly. I found this to be quite drinkable despite thehigher alcohol, I could certainly have enjoyed a few of these. Go Rogue!

Pours a beautiful golden-color with a creamy white head. Aroma is crisp and hoppy, but not too strongf. Flavor however, has a bit of a hoppy bite, but thats to be expected, I suppose. Its more like an IPA than a Pilsner because of the hops though. Definitely some alcohol flavor, but very primarily is the floral hoppy presence.

750 mL ceramic swing top bottle pours cloudy amber with little white head.  Head quickly dissipates leaving some nice lacing.  Light, delicate aroma of bready malts, quite dry with crisp hops, honey/floral sweetness, lemon.  Taste starts and holds with perfectly blended bready/biscuity malts and crisp hops, bit of spicy lemon/zest/pepper creeps in from the middle of the drink to the finish.  Honey/floral sweetness compliments the drink as a whole, finishes dry and slightly bitter.  Pineapple juice and grapefruit creep in as it warms.  Exceptional silky/frothy mouthfeel with medium body and carbonation.  Unbelievably drinkable; hides the abv very well.  Fantastic stuff.

Draft at Rogue Public House SF. Honey -golden pour, thin, lacy head. Lots of slow moving bubbles.Aroma- floral, hay, malt, hops. Taste- creamed corn, sweet malt, then flavor turns citrusy, dry grass, spices, pepper, bitter hops. Finishes creamy smooth and very bitter. Palate is phenomenal.

Pours a golden orange-yellow, with thin white head. Aroma is sweet, and some what fruity. Hoppy also. The taste is complex. Sweet up front with a bitter finish. Full body, pretty good, nothing amazing.

Creamy, fluffy off-white head.  Hazy orange color.  Nose is hoppy, orange/citrus and pine.  Big hop presence right up front but not over the top.  Well balanced and clean. Not overly bitter with fresh clean taste.  Tastes like a nice draft beer,

On tap at Issaquah Brewhouse. Rather hoppy on the nose, grass and pepper. Sweet and bready with hints of alcohol. Golden orange pour with a thin head. Bright and bitter up front followed by lots of bready malt sweetness, light grass, and almost big peppery/spicy bitterness that cleans out the finish. Some noticeable alcohol warmth is there too. Lingering clean peppery hops.

An unclear golden beer with a decent head. The aroma is real sweet. The taste is sweet  with a thicker body than a regular pilsner & hidden alcohol but is way too expensive & not worth the price tag except you get a nice bottle.

Pours a clear/bit hazy light yellow-gold from the 750ml swing-top ceramic bottle: The aroma is sweet for a pils and the taste is bold. Dry malts, and bitter hops dominate while some florals balance the overall feel. Drinkability: Strong and generous flavors- I definitely didnt expect to like it this much. Rebuy: Probably not only because its wicked expensive, but would like to enjoy it again. #160 on 25102009, DG.

750ml Bottle. Golden in color with a medium head and carbonation. Slight hop aroma but tremendous hops in flavor. Thought I was drinking India Pale Ale at first. Only a slight note of pilsner but great full hop flavor none the less that gives way to a slight bitter finish. A good, tasty brew that I would be happy to have more of.

Bottle 750ml swing-top. Poured hazy golden orange with an averaged sized, sticky foamy, off-white head which was most lasting. A fruity hop aroma with floral notes; sweet biscuity malts, caramel, overripe kiwifruit, canned pineapple and peaches. Flavor was a good spicy hop bitterness with sweet biscuity malts, caramel, hop resins, white pepper, kiwifruit, passionfruit, overripe nectarines and a dry grassy finish. Medium bodied with medium carbonation, a dry hoppy mouthfeel, slick texture and a long length finish. Extremely well balanced, very moreish  almost seasonable.

Golden with quickly disapating white head. Noble hop aroma with honey-malt backing. Hoppy flavour. Tastes of pilsner malt. dty finish. Alchohol increases as beer is drank. Medium body. very nice sipper

On tap at Rattle n Hum. Imperial pilsners are great. You get that crispness of a lighter beer with the alcoholic kick of a heavier beer. The Morimoto is a fine example of this preference. Pours a light yellow with a rich white head. Nose is dry hops and mild malt. Flavor is slightly bitter and hoppy. Body is decently carbonated. Overall a great experience.

On tap at Newport pub location.  Pours yellow with very little head.  Mild aroma of some sugars, citrus, florals, funk and alcohol.  Tastes of floral hops, finishes bitter and earthy with a tinge of alcohol.

Bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy gold with a medium white head.  Aroma has hops, straw, spice, floral notes.  Flavor is hops, spice, pineapple, malt, grass, bread, and citrus.  Bitter, spicy, fruity, medium-bodied, and a mild bitter finish.  I never expected something this good with Pils on the bottle.  Excellent for the style and Ill now be seeking out some other best-in-class of this type.
Light clear color nice thick head. Aroma of funk and grass. Taste of hops and bitterness with a bit of maltiness. Good carbonation. Pretty good stuff.

Source:Ceramic bottle. 
Glass:Snifter. 
Appearance:Hazy gold pour with a two finger white head.  
Aroma:Floral and spice notes with an odd fruitiness. 
Flavor:Biscuit malt base with a sticky citrus finish. 
Palate:Medium/full body with solid carbonation.
Overall:Enjoyed this more than expected.
Bottle purchased at Whole Foods in Bellevue, WA.  Pours a cloudy golden straw color.  Aroma:  Pineapple and hops.  Flavor:  Pineapple, sweet malt, with a hint of corn with a dry finish.

Interesting beer. Notes of pineapple on first taste which dissipate. Grapefruit in the middle and back end along with some non-descript spice. Maltier than expected but quite good. Perhaps not up to par with what you would expect from Rogue but still a quality brew that I would drink again.

Aroma is a nice little dash of hops, some zesty spice, and a floral notes.  The appearance is a very slight cloudiness and a thin white collar.  The flavor is a very definite oily hop, zest of grapefruit, with very nice malt bodies to compliment the assertiveness.  Complete from initial taste to ending, the first feel is the sensations of the flavors and the ending provides all the adjectives that can describe its intriguing zests, spices, and bites.  Very good, especially with pork kakuni.

It pours a rather typical clear straw-yellow, but gets a point for having a rather thick, fluffy white head. Aroma is strong and malty with a firm fruity overtone, mainly apple and lemon. Flavor is a bit bland and has an unpleasing metallic taste to it, but is still palatable. Texture is edgy and just a little tingly, nothing to write home about. This is the only Rogue beer I have ever tried that disappointed, but I will finish this bottle.

On tap at the brewery on 6/28/09. At brewery, tap was part of XS series, not sure if the recipe changed, or if the XS imperial Pilsner is different altogether. 

Pours beautiful gold with a solid head that lasts.  Nice floral aroma, with a touch of sweetness.  Super smooth and very drinkable, and no doubt the best pilsner Ive had to date.

Draught at Rogue in SF during RBSG.   Clear straw (pretty light for an imperial, but more like a regular pils) with a white head.   Spicy and grassy hop aroma with some sweet bready malt.   Lots of thick, doughy malt and spicy saaz in the flavor.   Not really that sweet or bitter, just more malty than a normal pils.   Thick body with medium carbonation.   An odd one.   Literally a pils but stronger, which actually makes it less interesting than the more out-there interpretations of the style.
The beer pours a hazy yellow with a thin white head. The nose is dry and sweetly hoppy. The flavor is an amazing full hoppyness with a hint of grassiness and malts. The finish is clean and dry.

RBSG09 on tap at the Rogue Publick House in SF.  Lightly hazy straw color with a frothy white head.  Noble hop aroma, very spicy, pils malt.  Lots of pils malt flavor, dough, fresh bread, noble hops reduced to an afterthought.  Dry finish with a light astringency.
Bottle.  Pours a golden body with a white head.  Floral citrus and earthy tones with grass and grapefruit.  Very hoppy pils, moderate etoh warming with citrus, pine, and grapefruit.  Nice pils.

Sampled on draft at Beer Run in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a very anemic looking hazy light amber with nearly no head. Aroma is strong caramel with grassy hop notes. Very is very strong and very bitter grassy and peppery hops with caramel and light tropical fruits. Medium bodied with a slightly sticky mouthfeel.

On tap at the Peekskill Brewery.  Pours a light hazy gold with a thin white head.  Light pineapple, citrus, pine, and caramel.  Medium bodied, very clean and hides the abv very well.  Finishes up with a nice pineapple and grapefruit note.  Very nice and almost blurring the lines between styles with some nice DIPA notes.  Tasty.

Its been a long time since Ive found this ceramic cased beauty.  I believe I was visiting relatives in Florida near Jacksonville and purchased these Rogues.

It poured smooth, foggy, and gold.  Fruity aromas filled the air around the glass and complimented the malty taste very well.  

Finished nicely, hides the 8.8 ABV nicely.  

Always a fan of Rogue.

***review from June 26, 2007***
Purchaced in early to mid 2006. Poured out a small off-white cap with a small ammount of retention that sat on top a viscus, cloudy, nice orangy gold brew. Lots of slow moving bubbs. Better than average lacing for a Pilsner. The aroma is nothing special although it does come across appealing, but still only average. You can note the grassy grain and a touch of alcohol but it is well hidden. The fruity aroma lessens along with the level of brew in my glass. There are also some soft biscuity malts. There is a touch of the ole grapefruit hops and some alcohol but the hops cover it up nicely. Decent malts too. Good bitter hops. Now that its warming, the bitterness has surpassed the majority of other flavours. There is other stuff to find but it comes and goes and is very faint. Medium bodied. If you suck on your tongue youll find that the hard bitterness never really leaves. A slight alcohol burn with some harshness as well. A smooth and highly drinkable beer that is totally overpriced but I guess the 20 bucks goes to the ceramic bottle.

Very lucky to get this last xmas, thanks eczmatic!  Drank in March. A little bit off putting in a ceramic bottle, but it poured a deep amber with a light, white head. A spicy, grassy green apple aroma, like a mince tart rolled down a hill i guess.  Certainly an intense mouthful, as the desc. puts it; for a pilsner.  Med. hop bitterness , alc. quite prominent.
poured cloudy golden.  smells of fruits, spices and kind of tart. taste is somewhat the same.  hints of hops not much. clean aftertaste. one of the better pilsners ive had.
Pours amber yellow with white head.  Aromas of sweet malts and spices.  Slightly hoppy flavor with malty alcohol on the finish.  Not the best from rogue and not really worth the price.

16 ounce pint - $7.25 at Taco Mac in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Clearish, golden body with a thin, white head on top.

Smell: Sweetish waft of pils maltiness rounded out by some earthy, spicy hops scents and unripened fruit notes.

Taste: Ponderous amount of pilsner malts downed with a spoonful of confectioners sugar. Interesting fruity blend of passion fruit, white grape, and tart pears. Small pinch of Goodys Headache Powder precedes a rustic, earthy, caustically pithy hop character with a pronounced medium-high amount of bitterness. However, the staunch bitterness really embodies the last half of the beer. Finishes dry, a tad warming, and bitter.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium carbonation. Theres a very light stickiness to the mouthfeel.

Drinkability: The heavy nature of these Imperialized, Double-fied pilsners totally negate the simple, refreshing qualities of a good pils. Starts engaging, but, for me, it soon grew tiresome and turned into the beer-equivalent of helping someone move.

This has been in my fridge for a while now, Iv just been waiting for just the right moment to crack it and since that will never seem to happen Ill drink it now.The beer pours a slightly cloudy honey brown and produced a thick white head that disappeared about half way threw the glass. The aroma is slightly sour, malty and had just a touch of hops thrown in, I didnt hate the smell but its nothing to get so excited over you piss your pants waiting for the first sip. I found the taste very refreshing and easy drinking what was surprising given the high alcohol content and thats probably because you cant taste the high alcohol. The beer is good and malty (sweet malts) and balanced with just a touch of hops, what is great for me because I find Rogue over hops most of there beers. Im finding this beer is tasting more like a less hoppy IPA then a pilsner but that really dosnt matter because Im enjoying it. The after taste is intensely bitter on the back of the tongue and just a touch of alcohol. This is a good beer not a great one, and would buy it again if it wasnt so high priced, but on a other positive side the 9% alc. knocks you on your ass after chugging the massive bottle however this may cause you to pee your pants.
Pine hops, a little floral perfume, smooth with plenty of malt. Goes down lovely!  Lovely grassy aroma, full bodied.

This beer rocks Its yellow to pour and has a fresh hop aroma thats a cross between the trditional european pilsner and an american pale ale. It has a sweet malty flavor thats fruity and very tasty an awesome beer.

750ml Ceramic Bottle:  Aroma of pale malts, grains, wheat, slight hops, and a hint of noble hops.  Poured gold/yellow in color with a medium to large-sized creamy, dense, rocky, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Hazy.  Not sparkling.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet and light to medium bitter.  Tastes of pale malts, noble hops, and slight grass.  Medium body.  Slightly sticky texture.  Average carbonation.  Lightly sweet, medium bitter, noble hop finish.8.8%ABV is well hidden.
I truly enjoy this beer.  Ultra golden pour, overall the body of the beer is the most full bodied pilsner I have had to date but is exceptionally smooth.  The finish is pleasant not overly.

a golden hazy pour leaving a white sticky foam. This beer has a grassy musky aroma the is inviting. The flavor is much of what to be expected of the aroma. The overall palate feel is smooth. A very good beer

Hazy golden pour, light white head with slight retention and good lacing. Lovely musty aroma, tree fruit, candy sugar, honey, barnyard. Flavour starts dry, develops a bit of honey in the middle, leaves a long, dry finish, and doesnt overwhelm with alcohol in spite of the Imperial name. Moderately light mouthfeel with good carbo. Excellent and something of a departure from traditional Rogue offerings.

August 26th 6:30pm 2008.. Quite a smooth brew, no abv detected... well made... pours a darker golden color .. . good foam .. . refreshing and upfront, an upgraded pils but not going into that malt liquor or ipa spectrum.. a smelly brown god?!?! what the hell?? .. at $17, its good but..i seemed to enjoy this more than the scores reflect...

750ml white ceramic bottle, cloudy honey gold hue, with a white head, yeasty, fruity, peachy, apricot nose with a nice floral hop citrusy, piney, leafy accent, with some grapefruit, lemon peel note, and some honeyed pale malt aromas follow through on a medium-bodied palate with a yeasty, fruity, honeyish pale malt character, with a flowery hop, candied lemon, orange, peach flavour, with  a honey lolipop sweetness, leading towards a citrusy, hop leafy, bitterness finish.

Birthday beer finally opened 7 months later...Cloudy, dark yellow/orange, foamy rocky white head.  Floral and citrus nose- hops smell awesome, even after being bottled for at least 8-9 months.   First sip (gulp actually) starts warm and sweet, like fruit cake, or shortbread or butter cookies, then transforms into a round, mellow bitterness- subtle and delicate.  Great body- full, good carbonation.  Just terrific.

Looked good in my new beer tasting glass, rocky, mainly lasting head on a orangey golden body, lots of lacing down the glass. Hops on the nose mainly mandarin and grapefruit. Citric hops are also there in the taste but not over the top and although the malt is in the background it plays a good supporting role. Was a little bit wary of thIs one but it went down very well.

On tap at Stone.  Hizy, bright yellow in the glass.  The fluffy white head drops to aemoba oil slick lace.  Sticky fingers cling to the inside of the glass.  Spicy white pepper and cream on the nose.  Hoppy pop of bitter in the mouth.  Pepper again.  Crisp with a HINT of lemon.  Crunchy at the end.  Yummy.

Had some trouble finding this one.  Finally found one in San Francisco.  A bit of a disappointment after all that.  Lets see, citrus, grass, caramel.  Has a citrus aftertaste.  Not dry enough for a pilsner in my opinion.  Still, quite drinkable.

Pours deep gold into a shaker. Bright white meringue head recedes leaving spider lacing to coat surface. Deep caramel and malt aromas. Creamy and full with upfront caramel and a lasting, dry resin and grapefruit finish.

750ml white ceramic bottle. Pours hazy gold. Small, short lasting white head. Aroma is composed of fruity and honey malt, some alcohol in the nose. Flavour is sweet malt, juicy citrus and some grass. Ends grassy with grapefruit bitterness. Medium body, tight carbonation. Better than I expected from a Euro strong, the hopping kept it interesting.

In short: A boosted Pilsner that maintains the characteristics of the style.  Unfortunately a little too sugary sweet.
How: Bottle 750ml (ceramic flip-top).  Consumed relatively fresh a few months after purchase 
The look: Cloudy dark yellow body topped by a medium white head
In long: Nose blends sweet fruits and noble hops.  Taste is crunchy crystal malts, sugary sweetness with a sensation of old honey turning sugary, light fruity note of apricots, a little alcohol bite, a good amount of dry grassy hops but not quite enough to properly balance the sugary nature of the beer.  Lacks the crispness and dryness of a good real Pilsner but as far as Imperial Pilsners are concerned (a bastard style that shouldnt exist) I guess this is a good one.  A bigger-is-better American pilsner with a Japanese name usually synonymous with smaller-is-better.  Like if Toyota called their Yaris the John Smith Sedan.

This is one of my favorites in the ceramic bottle series. Pours a cloudy golden color, and looks oh so unassuming. Plenty of frothy head and tons of lace. The aroma is dougy and mildly spicy. The flavor is very fruity spicy and doughy. The pilsner malt really gets a chance to show its stuff here. 
Very good.

750 ml. Clear, orange-topaz with a sticky head that lasts and cottons up the glass. Big aroma of grapefruit, orange, honey and resin. Flavor is similar, but has more hoppy resin-grapefruit and less malt-honey. Medium body is smoothly carbonated, hop-tingly and resiny-dry. Good, but wont revisit anytime soon due to the $15 price tag.
Bright golden orange in color and cloudy with a moderate whit head. Aroma is of oranges, hops, and peaches. Flavor is of citrus with a moderate hop bitterness.

Ceramic bottle, 8.8%. Caramelly aroma, a little alcohol. Hazy golden colour. Stable frothy head. The flavour is quite powerful. Caramelly, fruity, dusty. The alcohol is apparent in the mouthfeel and the finish.

Bottle. Resiny pine hoppyness in the nose.  Orange clouds, amber lacing cream. 
More balanced than expected, mandarine, citrus, grass on light hayish malt. 
Medium to light body, mellow mouthfeel
Gras retronasal. Pleasant enough.
Pours medium golden with a thin white head. Nose and flavor are yeast and spicy with some malt breadiness as well.

750 Ceramic Bottle. Poureda cloudy orange/amber color with a nice light head.  Good lacing on the glass.  aroma is maltier than other imperial pilsners I’ve had, but there’s a still a good hop kick. Almost like hop biscuits.  Flavor is big citrus hops although not as juicy as some.  More like the pith and less like the meat of a grapefruit.  Nice hops finish and a good mouthfeel. Good beer.

Date: 3/12/08
Beer info: Bottled in opaque white 750ml bomber 8.0%abv 

Sampling Notes:
Served chilled in pilsner glass.
Rich pilsner grain background, grainy biscuit, touch of vanilla. Hops come through in a torrent, bitter citrus grapefruit coming to mind, herbaceous and perfumey, sharp spice, hallmarks of Saaz hops or something similair. 
Hazy golden body, seems to get hazy towards the bottom of the bottle. Doesnt appear to be much beading and the small persistant white head suggests the same.
Big mouthfeel, huge length and bitterness to match, chewy texture, carbonation is low, and alcohol is slightly apparent in the sheer density.
Hops play through on the body, quite aggressive with bitter orange, grapefruit and lemon, as well as spice. Vanilla biscuit malt is a bit of an after thought, contributing to a draw out finish that isnt too dry, but clean and very bitter.
Big beer, certainly seems like a good pilsner but with big balls. Though I think the hop intensity as far as aromatics and flavour complexity, seemed a bit disappointing.

Decorative ceramic bottle.  Pours clear gold with a minimal white head.  Crisp and hoppy aroma with some malt.  Flavor is about the same, except you get the malt before the hop.  Not outstanding, but good.

750ml ceramic bottle. Pours a golden cloudy color with a white head that stays around. Hoppy bitter sweet aroma with some floral and grain hints.  Soft mouthfeel with a bitter finish.  The flavor is of citrus hops mixed with a little sweet maltiness in the back. But the hops really come through in this. One of the best pilsners I have had.

Superbe bière. Couleur or et long col persistent. Parfum riche et houblonné. Caramel et sucre. Miel et pomme.
Le goût est sucré et riche. Arrière-goût de houblon floral. Palais onctueux.

Misty gold colour,frothy head,ample carbonation,aroma,hoppy,perfumed floral fruit,detect some stonefruit.Flavour gritty a real blast of a taste,citric,stonefruit,great hop taste,the bitter is marvellous,oh for an even stronger pilsener,this one tastes so easy to drink,the 8.8% is hardly noticeable.The malt is there but minor to the other parties.It,s dry but not over dry.Finish hoppy dry,top stuff.
On tap - Poured a golden color with medium head. Aroma is piney. Flavor is also piney and bitter. I am not a lager guy but this beer is drinkable. High ABV. is a plus and finish is nice.

Rogue Brewing out of Oregon has a year-round profile which always manages to please, but to date their one-offs and specialty beers have been hit-or-miss, with the misses currently being in the majority. In particular, their ceramic series has left me far from impressed or tempted to enjoy another. Today I tackle another of their ceramic flip-top series, the Morimoto Imperial Pilsner. While the bottle is pretty, what lurks inside remains to be seen.

My Morimoto Imperial Pilsner poured a dark, almost dirty straw color with a small head which fades very quickly into a thin layer. A few repeated swirls produce a rather impressive scattering of lace which clings almost desperately to the sides of my glass. Her nose is an interesting array of dank grass, hard-boiled eggs, and fresh sticky pine sap. My first sip is sweet and then immediately followed up by a bitter bite which lingers long after. I am immediately reminded of a sweeter mild IPA and less of a pilsner, imperial or not. Sweet malts hint of caramel and honey with some herbal notes lingering with the sweet and resinous pine. As she warms, the biscuit and honey malts develop an off-flavor to them and more of the hard-boiled eggs I got in the nose come out to play. The ceramic container it comes in is large, and as I pour my second glass, some fresh melon and orange tease my nose but none are present in the palate. Dry and crisp in her finish with a tart, citric bit which hints of grapefruit. Right about now, Im not quite sure where this beer is going. While I have no intention of pouring her down the drain, Im not sure what it is I am drinking and what the Morimoto Imperial Pilsner is trying to tell me. I am left with a slightly sour and rotten aftertaste, sticky hop oils, and bland malty esters.

A very jumbled mess from start to finish, even my writing muse has difficulty making a cohesive summary of what exactly my palate is experiencing. I applaud Rogues efforts to try something new and different, but maybe instead of a pretty ceramic container, they should have concentrated more on perfecting and crafting a beautiful brew to go inside.

Rated 11/9/2008 (bottle): Pours a golden color body, somewhat cloudy and bubbly. Huge rocky frothy white head, lasting a while.  Hoppy bitter aroma, sweetness, and some floral-ness.  Some grain present too. Soft mouthfeel a little watery. Has a bitter aftertaste.  Grainy taste, maybe wheat or something. Bitter. Letting this one warm up a bit has minimal affect.  Thirst quenching.  Nice bitter taste.
(Ceramic Bottle).  Citrus aroma.  Hazy golden body, fluffy medium size head.  Delicious citrus and malt flavor, with a pleasing semi-bitter finish.  High quality, and high priced.

On tap at Romans.  Poured clear brighter golden with a creamy cap of white head.  The aroma was bright and vibrant with floral notes over sourdough bread.. juicy overall with medium-skinned fruits joining in.  The flavor found bread and honey sweetness at the core with plenty of spicy bitterness surrounding (floral, grapefruit, and pine primarily).. finished spicy with a rewarding warmth.  Extra-smooth on the palate with rolling carbonation.. ideal bitterness level.. great balance.  Excellent brew!

750 mL ceramic bottle. Pours a cloudy yellow with a small, white head. Little carbonation. Great Lacing. This is extremely hoppy for a pilsner- almost like an IPA wannabe. Aroma is- Im not kidding- pasture land or cow manure. Very earthy and dirty. Taste is grass with some pepper in there. Reminds me vaguely of a good Czech Pilsner- much sweeter than a Czech variety. Finish is bitter and resiny. Disappointing to say the least especially for the price.

Bouteille en grès de 750 ml obtenue via Iimportations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Odeur de céréales avec une pointe d’orange.  Apparence: La couleur est blonde voilée. Présence d’un moyen col mousseux et d’une large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût très présent d’houblon avec une pointe de miel et de céréales. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère amertume d’houblon en arrière goût. (Rating #1977)

Cloudy orange-golden poor, off-white head, good lacing.  Aromas of apples, pears, cider, caramel, ginger, celeri, light pepper finish... Fantastic! Balanced mouthfeel, lightly salty, medium-heavy body, very hoppy.  Flavors are all based on hops, caramel, gree vegetables, salty, oignons...

(Bouteille de 1 litre - Dégusté avec french tickler) Une biere de couleur miel brumeux avec un mince collet moyennement collant de couleur blanc. Odeur de pommes, épices, un peu d’humidité et d’alcohol. Gout de sel, d’humidité, d’épices et également un peu de citron.

On tap.  Light amber body with nice frothy white head.  Grassy hops with a caramel aroma.  Flavor is citrus, grass hops with sweet, delicious malts that finish with a wonderful bitter that nicely balances any sweet notes.  Palate is full and creamy.  Really good brew.

On draft, poured a dark golden with some cloudiness and a pretty decent white head.  Not much aroma.  Taste was a bit sweet for a pilsner, yet very smooth and refreshing, like a pils should be.  I found this surprising, since even the efforts of most of the best micro brewers ends up tasting like "good" malt liquor.  This was nothing like that.  I think maybe Rogue cracked the code on how to make a strong Imperial Pils that actually still tastes like a pils should!

(1 litre ceramic bottle) Purchased at 6 Mile Offsale for a wholly unreasonable $12. Pours a cloudy, deep golden body with a medium frothy white head. Nose is refreshingly pine hops. Nice Czech pils base with a great piney finish. Excellent. 8/4/8/4/16

No date.  Pours a hazy, deep golden color with a full, creamy, pillowy, brilliant white head; lating ability of the head is good with nice, scattered lace.  Nose is somewhat simple but pleasant and pungent; floral bouquet and overripe bitter oranges fill the bulk with mild hints at pine.  Flavor is unfocused but more complex with lavender, dry grass, pepper, light bitter oranges, and cereal notes.  Palate is mediumto full, lively, a bit warm, and sharp but somewhat creamy.  Finishes long and drying with lots of dry grass, spicy pepper, and herbal notes creaping in late and overpowering the finish.  This was interesting with such a high bitterness and not much malt backing but it was just not put together all that well.  All the hop flavors just did not seem to fit together.  Not worth the price.

Cool bottle and didn’t have to pay for it!  Liked this, seemed to have a nice round clean body to it.  Very cool, some light spice with a sweet malt earthy quality.  The ABV balances it out.  Have to say Rogue is shafting us with the expensive bottles but love Rogue brewery.  Liked this strong lager.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2008 Pours hazy golden orange with fizzy white head. Nose shows sweet malt and overipe fruit. Palate shows same with addition of intense floral spice due to rigorous hopping and high abv. Abundance of sweet malt adds great balance. Unsure as to what makes this a pils (obviously bottom fermented, pils malt etc)...certainly doesnt taste like a pils. Nonetheless pretty impressive.

I guess I am just a sucker to have paid $14.99 for the stupid ceramic bottle full of just average beer. Rogue really has got us beer geeks where they want us.  This poured a copper color with a nice fat white head and good lacing. Nose however is just strong citrus  and floral hops. Not much else.  Mouthfeel is crisp an clean, but not remarkable.  Flavor shows a lot of malts and is decently balanced with the hops. Alcohol shows in  the bitter finish. Smells and tastes more like an DIPA than a pilsner.  The best part of this was the bottle.
Golden in color with a very nice white head.  Smell is hops, malts, floral with citrus coming through from the hops.  Taste is a light to medium bitternes, some maltiness, floral.  Goes down easy.

Theres nothing at all practical about this beer so Im not gonna bitch about paying $16.99 and it being to high priced to make it practical to go into the regular rotation thus one and done. Huge white head. Taste is citrussy/lemony at first then a good crisp dry medium hoppy finish. Solid beer that I wish was could fit into the rotation but aint gonna happen. Oh well........

This is a tough one to rate.  I went to West Lakeview Liquors in Chicago, and told the beer guy that I wanted something special for my wife.  I told him she doesn’t like hops, and likes pilsners, so he suggested this one.  It was until we opened it that we realized it’s a hop bomb.  It’s much more like a double IPA, with strong malt and hops.  Needless to say, my wife didn’t like it!

That aside, I’ll rate it in and of itself.  Beautiful bottle, pours a murky gold/amber with frothy off-white head.  Aroma of strong hops, pine, citrus, floral accents, and malt.  Taste and mouthfeel is bitter, yet smooth and somewhat creamy.  It’s a nice beer if you think of it as an IPA, and not a pilsner.

Bottle shared bt SWOLF3! Thanks wolf! Well after a long weekend of work (CD08) , a cold beer tasted great.  Yellow in color not much head. Taste was more BITTER then I expected for a Pilsner. A good surprise though. Smooth and light. Over all a beer I enjoyed and would buy again! Thanks wolf!
Bottle from Sun Devil Liquors.  I held onto this one for a bit and when I finally had it I was pleased.  Dryer than I was expecting, notes of hop and light pepper.  A very refreshing beer.

Thanks to Irishboy!! Cheers Richard. Well, immediately one has to point out that the bottle is incredible, one of the best that has crossed my beer drinking path, certainly not one for the recycle bin. Appearance: Lovely healthy golden orange with a nice white head and visible carbonation. Aroma: Honey and toffee, almost smells thick! Some floral tones and malt in there too. Flavour: Honey and malt, fruity and some very slight but detectable citrus too! Grain finish with a definite honey finish, yum.
murky gold pour with a thin white head.  funky malts with an undertone of hops.  awesome thickness with lots of malts and a great hop flavor that is semi bitter.  very easy finish to this as well.

Gold color with a hoppy aroma.  upfront hop flavor with a subtle malt.  grainy, creamy, and even a tad bit of citrus.  smooth flavor with a dry finish and a wonderful lingering bitterness.  very enjoyable and surprisingly drinkable.

Pint bottle from Total Wine. Pours a honey-gold body underneath a tiny 2 cm. white head. Nose is grains and heavy cream. Very boozy taste with biscuits, surprisingly prevalent hop bitterness, and straw. Buttery mouthfeel and constantly grainy. This surely threw me off as it finishes like a pale ale. High carbonation and medium body. Good Pilsner, though difficult to drink.
golden with strong white head.  flavor is of munich malt with a strong hop bitterness and not the traditional pilsner crispness at the end.   a nice beer, but calling it a pilsner might be a stretch

Disappointing compared to the first time I had it a year ago. Both times were on tap. It seemed more grainy (not in a good or flavorful way). The hop profile was good-piny and floral, but it wasnt deeply rooted enough in the beer. The malt in this was the main disappointment.
Pours a thick, hazy gold with a frothy white head.  Bready nose with notes of grain and hops.  Very smooth dry hopped flavor.  It is quite remarkable.  It has just enough of a bitter finish too.

Pours a golden yellow color with a small white head.Slight aroma of grains and malt. Maybe a hint of hop.Flavor if some hops then a nice malt backing. Has a nice smooth mouthfeel with a slight bitter finish. Not Bad
Most hoppy pilsner Ive ever had. Pours with a heavy head and doesnt fizzle out. Very carbonated and extremely long-lasting bitter hoppiness. 74 IBU.

Clear yellow pour, big full white head. Aroma of alcohol, grains, grass, and some american hops, and malt. THe malt really comes through in the flavour, this is almost a malt liquor i find. Enjoyable though, glad i got to try it.

On tap at Rogue in Portland, OR--Poured a hazy yellow body with a wispy white head.  Nose of bold malts and bright hops.  Some sweet cloying grippiness midway through the taste.   A little thick after a while, but otherwise, quite good.

On-tap at Stone 5/8/08. Pours slightly hazy yellow with a small white head and some lace. Smells malty sweet and slightly hoppy. Tastes crisp and not overly malty sweet, has a bitter hoppiness right in mid sip as well. Lingering bitter sweet hoppiness. Full bodies but not overly thick or sweet like I was expecting. GOod carbonation.

Tap @ Blind Tiger.  Pours a cloudy golden color with a slight white head.  Aroma and taste are slight malt up front with monster hops in the background and a bitter aftertaste.  You can really notice the dry-hopping, as this is more overtly bitter than many other imperial pilsners Ive tried.
I dug this one, my favorite from Rogue actually. A powerful lager of raw strength and pure dominance. Got on tap at Rogue brewery.

750 ml. bottle. Not getting a strong aroma. The head is pretty tall and dense. The color is slightly hazy gold - loose protein? Some noble hop aroma as the head breaks up. Near medium body with creamy carbonation. Turns a bit thin as the carbonation leaves. Flavor is nicely bitter - grassy bitter. There is quite a bit of malt to go with all of that bitter.  Seems balanced. One of the hoppier lagers, but not quite so much as the Sam Adams version. Very tasty. A little spice, a little touch of fruit. Leaves the mouth rather dry and bitter.

Aroma: Rather faint; caramel malts and herbal/spicy hops come through. Kind of a pumpkin smell, as well, with just a hint of clove.

Appearance: Cloudy red-orange with an apple cider quality. Creamy but overly excited head dissipates rather quickly, leaving wispy, cobweb-ish lacing.

Flavor: Very fruity. Prune juice, orange rindy hops, and theres some banana action going on, like a dunkel weizen. A bit of powdery yeast runs through it as well, and just a drop of maple-like sweetness. This is not like any other pilsener Ive had before. It goes pretty well with my New Years Day dinner, consisting of roast goose, cranberry-pecan wild rice stuffing, and green beans. Alcohol is more present as it warms.

Palate: Medium bodied, and surprisingly sharp and dry.

Overall: I did really enjoy this beer and I recommend it, but I cant say Ill ever buy it again. At most places its $16 a bomber (I found it for $12), and Im afraid its just not worth that. Awesome bottle, though.

Pours to a hazy dark-yellow color.  Wonderful aroma of yeast and hops. Lots of flavor here -- lots of hops, some citrus perhaps, and a lasting bitter finish. Great pallet -- creamy, but not too much so. And that finish -- easily one of my new favorites.

Pours with a small, white head that goes quickly, covering a chill hazed, golden body. Aroma is hoppy, then sweet malts, some pilsner grass, and cornbread yeast. Taste is sugary and hoppy upfront with a long bitterness folowing. Creamy mouthfeel. Very ood beer style wise.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2010 Ceramic flip top bottle. Golden colored topped with a thick foamy off white head and lots of lacing on the glass. Aroma is quite grassy and malty with only a touch of hops and perhaps some hay notes as well. The flavor starts with some rich french pilsner malts then turns fruity, hoppy and sour. Sour aftertaste that sits on the tongue. More of a malt presence than I expected. Better as it warms. Definitely a good beer but something was just a tad off. Way too expensive but I guess thats partly because of the bottle.

Swing-top 750 mil ceramic bottle.  Nose is on the weaker side.. basic pils.  Pour is hued and almost hazy yellow gold.  Taste is wonderfully strong.. generous amounts of hops, florals, dry malt, and delicious alcohol.  Amazing how bold and rich it is for only 4 ingredients.  Reminds me of Pilsner Urquell on steroids.  Worth buying again, but I wish it wasnt so pricey.

this beer pours a hazy yellow with a medium white head.  I thought this was well crafted for an imperial pilsmer.  Really captures a pilsner doubled.  Nice hoppiness and not too sweet.  The finish is dry which really compliments this brew well.  Go and grab one!  Youll be glad you did!  Cheers!

Bloody pricey but my brother wanted the bottle for his collection.
Glad I tried it though.
Poured a cloudy golden orange with a nice thick head. Orange peel and clove coming though in the aroma with a nice hoppy flavour and a dry malt. I would probably love this on tap, top quality pilsner for me.

Big ceramic bottle from bottletrek.com  Very disappointed with this beer after all the hype.  At first pour there was very good color (a mostly clear, bright golden yellow).  A big, white billowing head with great lacing.  Aromas of Pilsner malt and hops.  the flavor started of very strange, chemical on the back of the tongue.  As the brew warmed it became much more enjoyable.  Who knows, I might have gotten an old bottle.

On tap @ Rogue Public House Portland

Pale orange-straw color, slight bit cloudy with small head that does some lacing.

Sweet light Pils malt, floral bouquet with a bit of grassy hops and some graininess.

Initial grainy Pils malt flavor builds to a bit of sweetness before the bitter floral hop bite comes to clean the palate. 

Moderate/medium mouthfeel, soft yet substantial. Pretty good for a Double Pils, but still not that drinkable.

Tasting session at Vinens Verden, Odense, 2007. The bottle is quite a piece of artwork in itself. Hazy golden with a low head. Grassy aroma along with some sweet malts. The flavour starts out like biscuits, pacman yeast and caramel, but then the hops starts kicking in aggressively and makes it a bitter finish. I do not find any resemblance to the lager-tradition.

Reasonable head, good, strong, flowery aroma. Cloudy gold color. Very nice taste, a welcome change from the IPAs that Ive been drinking lately. A sort of spicy hoppiness. A bit fizzy in the mouth, but goes down smooth with a nice aftertaste. Very good, well-balanced. Makes me feel like an Iron Chef.
Great sushi beer! Golden color with a nice head.  Flavor is hoppy but not to the point of being bitter.  Has a rich mouthfeel and a nice finish.

Bomber...poured a deep, golden yellow w/ a mostly diminishing, fluffy, white head. Great nose w/ hints of grass, citrus, sweet fruits. Tastes of bitter hops, a little apple, earthiness, and some florals. I love the nice hop bite complemented by the awesome bone dry finish. I could definitely see this paired w/ some California rolls. Excellent!

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2012 On tap many, many times at Tylers, Durham. This is the kind of beer that Rogue does really well, in my opinion. Theyve obviouslyl got a signature brewing style - big and hop-forward, usually with a nice chewy body - which lends itself well to certain kinds of beers, including this one. To me, what always makes this beer is the dry taste - not candied or too buttery like some versions - which complements the generous malting. Hallertau in here? Maybe, although theres certainly some floral stuff happening along with the more biting German hops. Very smooth drinker, though, which balances the whole thing out well.

Bottle from Trenton Takeout. Ok first off its a very cool looking bottle. Hazy golden pour with a definite grassy/hoppy aroma thats not an offensive punch. Strong dominant hoppy taste with a dry finish and some fruit. It is blended really good and is damn good beer.

Hazy amber with a deceny white head. Nice spicy herbal, grain bread malt aroma. Smooth, medium bodied with a flavor that mirrors the smell, bready cracker malts with spicy, herbal lager flavors. Pretty good  beer here. 5177

text: Pours gold/orange with a great fluffy head that laces nicely.  Aroma is floral and citrus that just smells delicious.  A very nice hop flavor that has enough malt in there to give it some sweetness to offset the hops a little.  A great beer.

Bottle, 1 pt, 10 ozs. Purchased at Kazanskys in Squirrel Hill, Pittsburgh for $10. This sells at Ds Six Pax for over $20.
Pours corn gold, white head. Aroma is hops (tangerine, kiwi), malt, grain. Flavor is hoppy, malty, bitter, sweet grain and leafy hops. Crisp, bitter finish. Good stuff.

Poured this into a snifter.  Slightly hazy deep  golden color with a white head that went away pretty quickly.  Very nice aroma of grassy hops and grains.  Excellent bitter hoppy flavor, and a smooth mouthfeel.  Best Imperial Pilsner Ive had, and one of my favorite Rogues.

Bomber - An untraditional pilsener... I love the stuff, it pours hazy and thick, with a thin, lacy head. Its like a pilsener on steroids, but breaking some of the rules... its more substantial. Cereal, malt, honey dominate. Good Stuf.

Ever have a cloudy sweetish beer calling itself a pilsner before?  Me either.  This wasnt a bad beer, but the marketing to call this an imperial pilsner annoyed the heck out of me.  Pilsners are straw colored, clear, crisp and refreshing, the opposite of this beer.  Doesnt have the characteristic lagered taste, I wouldnt be surprised if they used pacman on this beer but a tad cooler than normal, which is fine, but that is an ale yeast.  Anyhow, I was not impressed the several times that I had this beer.
Cloudy golden color; thin head. Sweetish aroma of cereals. Good body; malt and cereal flavor, sweet, quite strong bitterness; no crispy malt, no aromatic Saaz Unspectacular.

Bottle.  Sour peach/apple malt aroma.  Hazy yellow amber with large off-white head and nice lacing.  Apple juice, grass, and caramel malt flavor.   Light pine hops finish.   A very unique beer - extremely fruity for a lager.

On tap at Grinders in Kansas City, MO. Pours a hazy straw with a small, creamy, white head that leaves behind decent lace. The nose displays solid pilsner malt with nice, fruity and grassy hops. Medium-bodied with tons of fine carbonation and a lightly dry finish. It really struck me as amazing just how "big" the carbonation was in this beer. Until my tongue acclimated itself, the carbonation was actually a detractor to the experience. The flavor features tons of pilsner malt flavor up front (very sweet) with yeasty, grassy supporting notes coming in behind and concluding in a lightly dry, lingering finish (unlike a tradition pilsners quick, crisp finish). A very sweet and very "big" beer. A couple pints of this and youre set for the evening.

Success!  I finally found this one in San Diego at Servall.  And for only $15!  Pours like a glass of regular grapefruit juice, murky orange-yellow with a frothy white head.  Delicious aroma of hops, cornbread, sugar, grass, and cereal.  Smooth, sweet taste with more hops and a decadent Bavarian malt back.  An incredible all-around beer.
Porus golden with white head. Aroma is sweet malt, lots of hops, and a bit of citrus. Flavor is much the same with deffinate alcohol. Not sure how pilsner this is but A nice challanging beer.

Bottle.
Hazy amber coloured with a medium sized white head.
Malty aroma of hops and caramel.
Sweet and hoppy flavour of malts, caramel and grape fruits.
Light hoppy finish.
Nice fruity smell. Darker golden color. Very light and friendly on the palate. Slightly bitter, hoppy taste. Full mouth and light carbonation.

Strong aroma of hops some citrus fruit. Yeast. Cloudy golden. Foamy white head. I dont like the head.  Very light and hoppy taste.  Some yeast in the aftertaste. Spices and citrus.  Decent, yet there is something lacking.  Full mouthfeel, not too much carbonation. Good beer.

Sample, at the Mondial de la bière 2007, savoured June 1 2007; eye: golden, clear, no effervescence, tiny white head; nose: quite hoppy, grapefruit, citrusy, malt is barely detectable, fresh; mouth: attack in hops, dryness, grapefruit, dryness, alcohol but without its pepper, malt is barely detectable, long finale in a nice cutting hops, light astringency, medium body, quite bitter; overall: quite good

Served from tap in a sniffer at the Bocktown.  Ubiquitous american lager color but with a slight haze.Has the same aroma as many mild IPAs Ive tasted. Very bitter initial taste impact.  Also has a malt and alky character that gets in your face. This is certainly more than a regular beer. Decent carbonation and a very strong lingering finish. text: Slightly cloudy straw colored pour, smallish white head.  Nose is very light perfume, a bit flowery, very small amount of hops.  Light bodied palate with moderate carbonation.  The flavor is more of the flowery perfume from the nose.
For sure a big lager.  Not too pilsnery but good overall.  one of the best heavy light colored lagers out there.  Nice hoppyness and malty to pair.

It poured a pale yellow with a big white head. The hops came through first and lasted through a lingering aftertaste. The hops seemed to mask the effects of any malt. It was light and refreshing on a hot day, but out of balance. The term Imperial implies strong or extreme. In this case it appears to mean over-hopped.

The 22 ounce bottle poured a clear light orange-amber colored beverage with a modest sized white frothy head that was partially lasting and left good lacing on the glass. Be careful pouring ... this one is bottle conditioned. The aroma presents a crisp floral hop presence initially while underneath there lurks a subtle sense of roast malt, leather and nuts. The body is a mouth full and the carbonation is lively while the texture is smooth, creamy and inviting. The flavor starts out lightly bitter and grows to become a bit intense in the middle then fades toward the end of the long finish. There is a nice alcohol warmth in the chest at the end as well.

Dense, cloudy, glowing orange body.  Moderate, pure white head that settles to a thin film with a rim.  Ample legs reveal thickness, and give way to patchy ribbons of lacing.  The aroma shows big, toasty and buttery malts with significant floral hop presence.  Honey adds good balance to the nose, completing a simple, yet impressive scent profile.  Flavors are heavily toasty, with creamy, buttery toffee malts and significant hoppy bitterness.  Again, a few drops of honey save the day and make everything right.  Medium-full body that is somewhat sticky and ever so slightly cloying.  Bitter, floral hoppy finish.  Well crafted brew, and an excellent representative of the style.

Nov. 2005 - I really like this one. Typically I dont think of pilsners among my fav style, but if done right, these things hit the spot. Nice strong sweet aroma jumped from the glass. Beer poured slightly darker than some other pils, with nice head and lacing. Flavor was a lot sweeter than other pilsners, but nicely so. Probably my fav Rogue to date. Well done!

Pours a dirty golden color with a small white creamy head.  Aroma shows some grass, hay, pepper, cookie dough, white chocolate, and a slight flowery or perfume-like quality.  A lot going on for one malt and one hop.  Taste is earthy, peppery, slightly bitter, with a bit of white chocolate sweetness and some unmistakable pilsner funk.  Finishes with plenty of earthy hop flavor, some slight citrus flavors, and a nice flavorful bitter grassy earthy aftertaste.  Despite the small head, the beer was well carbonated and felt medium to slightly thick.  Creamy enough, but kinda light on the tongue, which a nice nod to regular pilsners.  Good stuff.

Had to buy it just casue of the bottle; Ive never seen a bottle that looks even remotely like this one. Pours an ultra-hazy gold with a large, sudsy white head. Aroma is of floral hops, lager yeast and sweet grain, pear/apple and a bit of must with some alcohol coming through. The flavour is hoppy, sweet and slightly vinous. The finish is bitter hopps that come across as slightly metalic. I also taste an earthy citrus, like lemon grass, which probably comes from the hops used. The palate is very full for the slyle and is oily and slick.

A) This is probably the coolest bottle I have.  Worth it for that alone.  B) Last time I had an imperial pils (DFH Golden Shower), I ended that night by yakking all over.  Those two things seemed to balance each other out, leading me to like this beer but not love it.  I cant really explain it any better than that.

One of the finest pilsner I have ever had, delicious with sushi or tuna tartar.  Fantastic that you can have a delicous crafted beer at a top-notch restaurant (Morimoto 7th and Chestnut, Philly).  Cheers to Rogue for creating another classic beer.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2007 When I tried it on tap at the Seattle Intl. Beerfest, I found this to be exceptional and wish I could have pint after pint. I hate to say it but I was disappointed with this promising attempt at the Imperial Pilsner when I bought the gorgeous ceramic flip-top bottle. Certainly its floral and has a sturdy build but the beer seemed all hopped up--and not in the right ways. However, I aprpeciated the enthusiastic foamy head and rich golden color. The aroma and aftertaste both burst with hops. Would love to try it at the brewery someday to see what the tap version is like away from the brewfest.

Pours nicely with a thick head.  Sweet, flowery smell, but not pungent.  Nice initial taste with a burst of bitterness, much like an old, european pilsner (Pilsner Urquell).  Overall, not quite worth the price for me.

pours a cloudy yellow-orange with a 4 finger head, much carbonation.
smell is very floral, sweet, and mandarin orange.
taste is more like an IPA than a pilsner, sweet tart, citrus (lemon & orange), bitter-sweet, hops, yummmm.
i was not expecting this taste at all, very smooth, nicely bitter, exceptional brew, way to go iron chef.
This had an awful taste to it. The bottle was amazing looking but the beer had a horrible taste.

Cool ceramic bottle.  Cloudy yellow with a fizzy white head.  Floral sweet malty aroma.  Perfume hops taste in the back of the throat strong weet maltiness and a good bready taste to the finish.  Alcohol well hidden.

White ceramic bottle (pricey).  Pours a clear gold (slightly hazy) with white fluffy head.  Pretty nice aroma of sweet malt, grain, grass, earthiness, and hops.  Flavors of sweet grainy malt, bitter hops, floral, a bit of fruit, and finishes with alcohol.  I like it, but in a way I dont.  Interesting brew.

Draft at Waldo Pizza in KCMO.  Pour is golden with some haziness which cleared.  The aroma was bright hop, earthiness and honey sweetness.  The taste is big, sweet honey.  I was surprised by how big this flavor was, and I found it a bit cloying.  As my senses settled in, this beer was more or less enjoyable, though the sweetness did numb my palate.  The finish has a bit of alcohol, though nothing overpowering.

I honestly did not like this, but give it extra points for Rogue being willing to take a risk.  Draught at Rogue Pub.  Yeasty aroma.  Very frothy with white head.  Taste of alcohol, with some maltiness.  Alcohol and yeast finish.  Somethings should not be imperial, IMHO pilsener is one of them.

text: Light yeast aroma with moderate hops. Cloudy gholden color. Fizzy with a medium white head. Starts off hoppy finishing with a fruity yeast taste.

Pours a deep and very cloudy gold with hints of orange. It pours up an immense, cloudy, uneven, off-white head that laces the glass heavily and lasts impressively - fading to a persistent, medium-sized, rocky layer floating on the beer. The aroma is an excellent mix of malt and hops - big, chewy, sweet, malty smells mixed with fragrant, grassy, almost perfumy hops. The aroma, overall, leans towards the malts. The first sip has a delightful maltiness. The tip of the tongue detects the sweet flavors of caramel and honey mixed with bitter and flowery hop flavors - again, leaning more towards malty and sweet. The middle of the tongue detects a more complex balance - a taste of peppery, bitter hops slowly begins to balance the huge malt presence. By the end, the back of the tongue tastes a very well-balanced, hoppy mixture that has begun to lean away from the malts and towards the hops. Masterful. The finish is medium in body and long. The after-taste is a rich mixture of grassy hops and faint notes of honey. The mouthfeel is a bit thick, but is well tempered by the carbonation resulting in a creaminess that hides the heavy body. The alcohol is virtually undetectable too - it is very well hidden. Overall impression: a very tasty strong lager with interesting layers, or "waves", of flavor. Also, it came in a kick-ass bottle that includes a free-hanging pop-top (as the bottle is capped) that could be used if you dont drink the whole thing at once (all 26 oz.).
Bottle, 22oz. Nice ceramic bottle. Clear yellow color. Very hoppy aroma. Flavor is rich on hops, with notes of grass. Good mouthfeel. This beer will proberbly gain a lot with ageing.

Pours hazy orange with a sudsy light beige head.  The aroma has pils malt thats thick with mild honey sweetness and grass.  Medium / thick body with a lush syrupy feel with some sharp carbonation giving it a bit of crispness.  The taste starts with lots of maltiness, some sweetness and grainy / grassiness.  The finish has some hops coming in that are more earthy than spicy.  A nice beer, but not really worth the $14 price tag.

Very cloudy golden with a large head, decent lacing and retention. Aroma is grassy, spicy hops with loads of a soft bready malt backbone. Medium bodied with a bittersweet finish. Certainly enjoyable, I really liked it. However, paying an extra $10 for the bottle is ridiculous.

Ive had this one for a couple months now. A warm day helped me decide to finally crack it open. Morimoto Imperial Pilsner pours with a glug glug into a pilsner glass. A beautiful crystal clear golden body fills the glass. Numerous big carbonation bubbles rise rather quickly to the 2 finger craggy white head that forms. The head eventually falls to 1 finger and leaves spotty lacing. A really wonderful looking beer.

The smell is inviting and refreshing. Clean raw graininess along with a nicely subdued hay and grassy hop aromas. Theres a mild sugary sweetness in there as well.

This is a truly refreshing beer. Very simple flavors yet theyre very well rounded and in perfect balance. Raw graininess starts things off and is present in the background throughout. Mild grassy hops show up midway through along with a subdued sugary sweetness. This sugary sweetness actually compliments the other flavors very nicely. Nice hop spiciness on the swallow. Every now and then I get mild alcohol fumes on the swallow.

Body is surprisingly light for such a high ABV. Good carbonation keeps things moving and awakens the tongue. Finishes dry and very crisp. Refreshing.

This is an easy beer to put back. I could easily see myself drinking this all day long and I would if I could find it for $5.99 all the time.

This is a superb beer from Rogue. Unbelievably refreshing and crisp for such a high ABV. This is usually an expensive bottle but I would definately suggest trying it at some point in time. Excellent!

Unclear golden yellow with a small white head. Grain and hops in the aroma. Very bitter and with some alcohol noticable.

Not a bad lager, but Ive been more impressed with other offerings from Rogue. Hazy, golden body and a snow-white head. No lacing. The flavor consists of a huge dose of both malts and hops -- much more than I was expecting, to be quite honest. Mildly bitter aftertaste. Mouthfeel was quite heavy, and the carbonation level was about average.
Fresh hoppy smell. Dark gold with a big fluffy white head. Hoppy but light. Very fresh taste. Thick mouthfeel for a lager. My kind of lawnmower beer

Poured a cloudy orange with a big, thick foamy well retained cap.  Smells of hops, some malts, a little sweet smelling.  Taste is fairly simple, hops are present but more subtle.  Bitterness is ever present, so typical in pilsners for me.  A little bit of a sweet caramel taste in the finish.  Not one I could drink easily.  Definitely a big pilsner, the alcohol was prevalant.  Not bad.

intresting nice floral hop aroma, very cloudy especially at the bottom which was almost milky, orange colour, nice white head, good hop flavour good and crisp. had at castros but its available at Volo

Cloudy yellow colour with a white head. Malty, fruity and light sweet aroma with grassy notes. Malty, sweet flavour with notes of fruit and alcohol. Light hoppy and dry finish.
