Citrus.  Very dry.  I dont think it has much to offer other than a killer amount of hops.  80 tons of one ingredient does not a great beer make.

Cloudy Orange Coloring.  Small White Head.  Aroma: Citrus, Hops.  Dominating Hops in Beginning and End of Beer.  Very Dry...Almost Like you Cant Classify it as a Liquid in Your Mouth.   Floral Taste Right Before it Hits Your Lips.  Extremely Distinctive for a Pilsner...Not my Favorite, But its Own Beast.

Pours deep gold and cloudy. Big, nicely lacing, pure white head. Huge sweet hop and antiseptic aroma. Notes of chocolate and light vanilla. Thick mouthfeel, but plenty of carbonation. Wicked bitter, or rather bittersweet as you get past the initial shockwave. Herbacious and mediciney. Some late caramel. Alcohol burn kind of like malt liquor. Finishes clean and dry.

This very nice ceramic bottled brew with a flippy top and marked best before 7/1/2005 poured a very large sized head of large sized white colored mostly lasting bubbles.  The body was hazy carbonated and a golden orange brown in color.  It had a very nice pilsnerish malt hop aroma with some doughy notes.  The mouth feel was tingly and hoppy more like an IPA than a Pilsner. It had a caramel malt hop flavor that was not right for the style.  It tasted even more l9ike an IPA after I got to finish the rest of the bottle by myself.  What a buzz though!
This is a Good European Strong Lager.  Hoppy, malty, and some sweet flavors.  Dry, clean, and bitter finish.

Coolest bottle I have ever seen.... definitly adding to the keeper collection. Light golden color. Fruity lemon aroma. A zesty ale with some hops. This was a very enjoyable beer, nothing too hard on the palate. Only problem is the price, but obviously a lot of it is the bottle. I am just glad it isnt all show with the bottle, there is actually some great beer inside too.

hazy, deep golden color, head is thin, white. some alcohol in the nose, lots of spicy, herbal, earthy hops. Pretty damn malty, flavor is quite bitter, but pretty damn sweet too..finishes with a citrusy quality. fairly alcoholic presence in the mouth. its good.

This bottle has to be about the most rad thing ive seen in a while, but unfourtunatly i think you pay for that. Pours a cloudy orange with a tall soapy off-white head. Aroma is wheaty and hoppy. Taste starts a bit malty and sweet but is quickly taken over by the bitterness. Very smooth mouthfeel with a nice crisp hop taste, very clean tasting for a double.

Hazy orange with tight bubbles.  Really piney nose.  Really pleasant silky palate, with a pretty sweet overall feel to the malt profile and a citrus tang to the hops.  Long dry finish, with hints of pine sap and wood.  This was one damn big pilsner!  Cool bottle, but Id rather have the same beer in a normal bomber or 6 pack and save some cash.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2005 Bottle. Pours yellow/orange, with a white head.Slight hop/pine aroma, with some sweet malt as well. Taste is that of an IPA, citrus/pine hopiness. Starts out sweet, ends bitter from the hops. Some sweet orange in the taste as well. 
They should really make this in a more normal bottle and make the price more affordable. Then, Id drink it more often.

Cloudy amber orange in color.  Almost no head, but what is there us very large bubble.  Apricot aroma. Taste is watery up front with a fruity finish.  Not really a pilsner in my mind but it does finish like a pilsner, with a malty like texture.

Slightly cloudy pale golden orange, thick bright white head. Piney, vanilla, orange/citrus, gooseberry quality, with sweet malt nose and marshmallow.  Light prickle in the mouth, sweet malt, lingering hop finsih with vanilla pine nad orange...Very good, though I would drink more if the price was a bit more reasonable.

Pours a deep straw colored brew that raises a very active whipped cream like head. Nose is slightly hoppy with an herbal quality to it. First thing I noticed was a overlying sweetness to this brew. Kind of reminiscent of honey. Finishes with a dry herbal hop bitterness that is very subdued.

Bottle. Large white head with fine-medium sized bubbles that were mostly lasting. Fast rising carbonation, semi-transparent and a gold hue. Lacks aroma. Malty and hoppy aroma. Bitter, hoppy, acidic flavor with a hoppy aftertaste. This reminded me more of a Pale Ale than a Pilsner as the bottle says it is. Too hoppy for a Pilsner IMO. Tingly and hoppy mouthfeel. Fair lacing. Not a beer that I will drink again.

Slightly hazed orangey amber appearance, thich rocky white head of foam. Intensely fruity aroma, tropical, apricots, peppery spice and slight woody grain. Smooth syrupy palate, medium bodied, biting and refreshing towards the end. Sweet tropical fruits, alcohol noticeable in the back half, dry with a significat bitter hop bite in the finish.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, white, mostly lasting. Body is
hazy dark yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted bread), lightly hoppy
(herbs, flowers). Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately
bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, heavily bitter.
Medium to full body, velvety/creamy texture, lively carbonation, lightly
alcoholic. The almost total lack of an aroma is the only problem with
this one; the mouthfeel, flavor balance, appearance, and dangerous
quaffability are very nice indeed. Really sad about the aroma.

Slight hazy golden color,small but long lasting white head that leaft a good lace behind.The aroma was light sweet malt with a citrusy side mild hint of spice and a nice hop presence.Good malty flavor,with a slight sweetness in the beginning that changes towards the end to a mild alcohol burn and some nicely done hops.mildly fruity taste(citrus) with a nice almost creamy mouthfeel.Not a bad brew at all,no where near a pilsner as the label proclaims.I could go for more of these for sure.Thanks go to Jpdipso for sending this fine brew my way.

Wow.  First, I must say that I dont much care for pilsners.  That having been said, this was exceptional.  Thanks to a beer buddy for sharing this.  Beautiful bottle.  Pours a cloudy amber with a nice white head.  Aroma is slightly sweet, hops, floral, nice malt.  Mouthfeel was rich and robust and full.  Flavor was nice blend of malt and hops, acidic and alcoholic.  Great stuff for a pilsner.

There I was at Morimotos restaurant on my 10th year anniversary when I looked at their beer list. Should I spend the $24 for this beer - what the hell, it was a special occasion and I was interested in what an Imperial Pilsner tasted like. Came in a cool bottle which I took home with me (extra point). Poured a hazy medium amber with a large off white head. Hoppy floral aromas with malts. Sweet tasting with a nice bitter finish - well balanced. Being a hop lover, this beer worked well for me. A nice surprise. I would get it again for a cheaper price.

Bottle.   A hazy orange yellow color with a creamy off-white head.  The aroma has a light citrus fruitiness and herbal notes.   A slight medicinal flavor on the otherwise floral and spiced flavors.  A thick palate, as expected.  This beer is "different" and interesting but not something I would generally return to.

Thick lightly hazed golden liquid. Stable moderate off white head. Fresh, somewhat earthy, hops aroma. Hints of malt. Very sweet start. Heavy hops acid and light alcohol late. Not as clean and crisp as a pils of any sort should be. Once again this is more a malt liquor than a pils. Interesting enough though.
UPDATED: MAR 3, 2005 I believe I had this from the tap at Monks in Philly. Solid Pilnser with great ABV.

Slightly hazy golden yellow with a thin, persistent white head.  The aroma is crisply hoppy with a clean, grassy malt pressence.  The perfume of a lawn after an early morning, summer rain.  Fresh flowers and wet pine oscillate in and out of the picture.  The body is slightly heavier than youd expect for a pilsener, but at 8.8%, not too bad.  The effervescence is lively on the tongue and produces lots of tight, tiny bubbles.  Slightly sweet on the tip of the tongue.  As we move to the back, the hoppy bitterness picks up and becomes wonderfully refreshing.  A perfect summer body with plenty of character and body.  Another winner from Rogue.  Outstanding.

Very thick and heavy.  Grassy and floral aroma.  Rich malty and grassy  body, hay-like dryness at the finish of even the smallest sip.  An interesting beer in one of the coolest bottles to be found.  ($20 at Happy Deli in NYC, but only $14 at New Beer Distr).

The first thing that struck me about this beer was its palate: very thick, almost syrupy.  Thick hops flavors are expected and found in the finish.  Floral aroma.  Even with the hops it struck me as being a sweet beer.  Not so much a pilsner, but an interesting take nonetheless.

Somewhat hazy yellow with orange hues and a big white head.  The aroma contains some light and sweet malts and a present bitterness, but is somewhat plain.  There is a sharp mix of crisp malts and pine bitterness in the taste are nice.  It has some underlying pils tones that are fairly standard for the style, but which do remind you that it is a pilsner at hart.  The imperial moniker does make its presence known as you taste the hops.  Its a nice change of pace for a pils, especially for a hophead.

Very strong for a pilsner but I guess that is what they wanted to achieve.  Quite malty and a nice floral taste.  Very cool bottle too.  Anyway I agree with one rater that it blows the tradition of Pilsners away as like Pilsner Urquell.

Thick head on this, with a nice malty aroma. The hops dont make their presence known until the beer is in your mouth. This is an idealized pilsner, and totally devastates the traditional examples such as Pilsner Urquell. The ceramic bottle ensures no skuny aromas, and the high alcohol level give this a belly-warming quality I havent encountered since Russian piva.  It is pretty expensive, which is a shame - as this is a beer that people should be drinking, in large quantity.

Light frothy head.  I called an opaque golden color, but that was because I was poured the bottom of the bottle.  It had a distinctly alcohol smell, and taste, though not bad.  It had a smooth palate with a nice presence of hops.  One I enjoyed and would again...if purchased for me...which is possible seeing as Im a gal.

This beer poors a rich golden color with a frothy whit head.  Significant and attractive  champaign type bubbles.  Aroma give a hint of alcohol and malt but the predominant aroma is herbal types hopps.  Flavor is moderately sweet. (almost cloying but not quite at that level).  Fortunately the hopps soom make their presense felt with a nice bitter finish.  The overalll effect is nice and unusual for a pilsner.  

This was too expensive for a repurchase but definately a nice attempt by Rogue.   Check it out.
Nice cloudy golden color.  Very crisp fruity taste.  I love the bottle.  A little pricey though.  I really like it though

Floral aroma with blending of malt. Crisp excellent pils. SO much alchohol, but well masked by the above. Light on tongue, light carbonation. Lace. Even fruity yeast. Dry aftertaste but satisfying. A beautiful bottle with a cap. Enjoy the weekend together.

Cloudy bright golden color, frothy white head, lacing. Nose of fruity (slight) apricot, floral. Nicely balanced between the dry aggressive hops and the bready peppery malts. Bad ass pilsner with a bad ass price tag. Extra overall point for the bad ass bottle.

This beer has a really great bottle as you can see to the left.  Like Drew, who reviewed this beer right before me, I was inspired to drink this beer by Iron Chef America.  This pours a nice gold color with a long-lasting off-white head that leaves good lacing.  Aroma is somewhat fruity with some really great floral notes and some spice.  Flavor is really nice.  Very sweet malt notes but in a bready sort of manner.  Also, some nice fruit notes peek through the moderate hop bitterness.  Body is silky and rich with a long finish.

Morimotto vs Mario Batali in the Iron Chef kitchen - yeah!  How could I not be inspired to open this beautiful bottle and enjoy????  This poured out glowing yellow gold - the light just shined all over the place - huge head that lasted forever; fantastic slippery lacing.  Aroma was sweet, floral, and a little peppery - I got a sharp bite in my nose that almost made me sneeze.  Bread and sweetness in the malts - body was almost thick - hops were pepper at first, similar to a pils, but also a wood-oaky-edge to them - that seemed to mellow out as it warmed.  Very drinkable, I didn't notice the 8.0% abv til I stood up!  The darn bottle is too heavy - I kept thinking that there was more beer to pour!  Eventually, Mario won, both chefs made me feel very hungry, and I really wish this was available as a lower priced six pack, it could be my ULTIMATE LAWN_MOWIN' BREW!!!!

Appearance, clear golden color, under a full, frothy white head. Looks good so far!
Nose is fresh, floral, herbal, perfumey, even, clearly we're in the presence of a mighty pils in this one.
Taste: ahhh! Big blast of hops right off, with a rich, tasty mouthfeel, some fruitiness peeps on board the palate, peach and cherries, it's rosy, fruity, yeast, malt-alicious!
Spicy, solid, overwhelmingly flavorful, and -Boom, chick-a-boom, don't cha just love it?, this packs a damn punch, indeed!
Pilsnsers aren't supposed to be like this, 
are they? It's a bad mamma jamma, and I forgot how potent she was, until I had to reckon with the ringing, next morn
Cloudy copper color with a big foamy head. Awesome sweet tangerine flavor. When the temp comes down, the alcohol really jumps up at you. Sweet, dry, gritty finish. Superb.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2005 Late 2003 or early 2004 ceramic bottle.  Very golden, thick and juicy looking, with some orange-amber and hazy golds.  Big creamy white head. Smells crisp and hoppy, not quite as sharp and clean as a true European pils, but still quite crisp and light.  Flavor opens up immediately with some vanilla flavoring, mabye some dry almond liqueur as well, creamy and smooth with a good amount of sweetness.  This transitions in to a big hops flavor that is quite citric, like a ripe naval orange, sweet and tangy.  Ends with a good enough yeasty, caramelly, hoppy mix and plenty of herbal notes as well (juniper, some pine), and Ive got to say I like the flavors, but I just cant get past the use of overly bitter, citric hops in a pils.  Why cant they just use a ton of hallertauer, or tettnangs??  Still, this beer does taste great. 7/5/8/4/16Feb 05 draught at Anam Cara Good transluscent color, small white head.  Aroma of sweet pils malt, lightly sour yeast and a definite dose of raw alcohol.  Light yellow fruits, nectarines, peaches, apricots as well as some honey tones.  Taste just seems to have a touch too much alcohol.  Its not terribly apparent, but just enough to be annoying.  Its not terribly out of style, as every other ESL Ive had has a bit of a harsh grain alcohol taste to it, but I still dont think it belongs.  Decent flavor other than that.  7/5/7/3/14

Rating # 442
Yep, its True! BeanDip and the Monkey were the hosts of the Year for supplying yet another awesome brew at our tasting last Friday evening.
 That stoneware crock is cool as hell, but dont you think its a little excessive? 
Poured a nice pale coppery body and a bountiful rocky white head. What the Hell is Pils about this beer? Nothing at all!
I thought the beer was great! The aroma was citric and packed with caramel with caramel. I was digging the flavor; I drank most of the beer because every one else thought is sucked. The finish was sharp and dry woody, with notes of tangerine zests. 
 The palate was oily and chewy. I really liked it and would drink it more often if I had $12 to drop on 1 single bottle!

Cloudy like a hefeweissen. Rich, buttery apple pie aroma. More hops than most pils and has a slightly sweet note. The mouthfeel is strange, like flour. Tastes a little like a glazed donut. This is very good, but not worth the price. The bottle is really cool, though.

Hazy light orange-blonde coloured body with a nice dense white head. Aroma of bright citrus hops, peaches and light malt. Meidum-bodied; Hoppy flavour with a chewy mouthul. Sweet taste in the middle, then fades to a hop bitterness. Aftertaste bittered, but nice! Overall, a great beer to try-many thanks to Phil (haddon90) for bringing this bottle up to me!

Brilliant gold, but gets an extra appearance point for the ludicrously cool (and yet obnoxiously expense-causing) bottle.  Not sure about the scent.  Something overly sweet and strong is going on that overpowers some hops and fruit.  Quite dry, strength is noticeable at the swallow.  There is an aftertaste that's a bit sticky and somewhat cloying, sweetness hangs around a bit too long.  Peach and a bit citric undertones, swear I got a Cascade-y hint right before the swallow.

26 oz bottle-pours a slightly darker than normal lager golden yellow.  medium carbonation with a rocky white head.  smells like a very hoppy/yeasty lager, but still very lager-like.  straw and spicy hops on the aroma.  sweet, surupy palate with stiff bitterness-very gin-like.  as it warms, a peach note comes out in the aroma-well balanced and no sign of the 8.8% anywhere to be found!  Another very well done brew from Rogue and this done didn't give me a headache.  Big thanks to whaleman for hooking me up with this one!

Small head that disappeared quickly.  Nice light orangish color.  I like the hoppiness, but I don't really like the mouthfeel or the aftertaste.  I generally don't like pilseners, but I wouldn't turn one down if offered.

Pours a hazy light orange colour. .

Aroma is sweet, dried apricots, and some light alcohol notes.

Flavor is sweet, golden raisins, candi sugar, spicy bitter saaz notes, and a wee bit of alcohol. 

Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy. 

Very tasty, probably up there with the most full pilsners I've had, the only other one I can compare is New Holland Full Circle, but that one uses an ale yeast, the Morimoto has a lager yeast.

Whatever super tasty brew, both of 'em.

This pilsener pours with a golden orange body topped by a thick white head with lots of lacing.  The aroma is slightly sweet and grassy with a slight hoppiness.  The flavor is slightly sweet and lemony with a nice maltiness and a pronounced piney, bitter hoppiness.  Medium bodied, smooth and tingly from the carbonation, with a slight warmth and a touch of dryness.

Bottle pours a hazy yellow orange with a big white head and very sticky lace.  The aroma is hops and brothy malt.  The flavor is malty sweet with a good hop attack.  The palate is good and rich.  This is one fine Pilsner.
Dingy looking light orange body with a rockey white head that dissapates fast.  Lots of hops in the aroma along with a slight berry smell.  Same goes for the taste.  Very good brew

frosted yellow tainted gold with a gigantic crown shaped head..musty grains aroma with sweat laced socks and subtle banana plus some growing mango sweetness behind a touch of must...at first, alcohol was almost unbearable, but after drinking more it seems to subside...at first, a bit syrupy and almost malt-liquor like...but after consuming..more mango sweetness comes through, hiding some of the alcohol...straw-like bitterness behind this..growing fruity sweetness...not bad really...you can tell its not an ordinary pilsner though.

The sweetest and hoppiest pilsner I have ever had. It is truly an extreme pilsner. The mouthfeel and taste are creamy.  The abv is totally hidden and sneaky. The bottle is a bit much and not necessary imo.  I like the art but its the contents on which I judge and bottom line I would simply buy this all the time if it weren't 11.99 a bottle.

First of all, this is the best goddamn bottle in the entire world! And due to that fact, it automatically gets a bonus point in appearance. It pours a cloudy yellow with some orange hints and a very heavy soapy white head which gave up after about a minute and a half. Really though, the aroma on this makes you kinda wanna go, "HUH??!!". A very wheaty smell at first with woody and citrusy banana hints. There's also a little bit of a corn and floral aroma..but a small hint. The flavor definitely seeps of alcohol. In fact, it was incredibly disappointing to taste just how much alcohol was present...at only 8.8% you would think they could have done more to prevent this from happening. Heavy malt front iwth a very woody and hoppy finish. Can we say hello to the Sterling hops. There also seems to be a good hint of lime in mid taste and some citrus in the finish. For something so simple this has a lot of stuff going on! Very multi-layered finish. Complex and fun to say the least.

Nice ceramic bottle!  Ya gotta love that, with the Grolsch-style rubber stopper and all.  It would seem that Rogue is wisely cashing in the trend of calling everything "Imperial".  Can't say I blame them.  This is a pilsner with lots of bite, though perhaps not the Victory Hop Devil of pilsners.  It's also not short on flavor, boasting French Pilsner Malt and 100% Sterling Hops as ingredients.  The beer itself is rather dry and floral with lots of herbal fragrances wafting from the glass.  I don't taste the citrus others do, but the malt is very present for a pilsner - very sweet and spicy.  An odd mix that most will find as enjoyable as I did.  Recommended, even though the huge 1 pint ceramic bottle is quite pricey!

Dark orange gold color. Large foamy white head. Aroma is wheaty and citrusy. A full bodied Imperial Pilsner. Malts are fruity and sweet. Hops are spicy and green, and a nice introduction to Sterling hops. Very complex beer for one made with only one malt type (French Malt), one hop type (Sterling) and a Czech lager yeast. You pick up different aspects of this beer with each taste. Hoppy and citrusy mix tastes with orange and wood. Fairly smooth, but there is a definite hop kick and a slightly alcohol bite. Very cool ceramic pained bottle. Nice beer, but a difficult one to describe. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2004 An Imperial Pilsener...was not sure what to expect. $13.50? Well it must be good -and Rogue would not make a bad beer now, would they? Well, it is not bad, but get off the Sam Adams high horse and bring the price back down to earth! Rant over. 

Faint, fruity, pear-like aroma, dark golden pour with a generous white head and thin lacing. Sweet, tangy flavor with slight traces of honey and a significant sprucey hop presence. Thick, creamy mouthfeel. 8.8% alcohol is hidden very well. Very good hoppy rendition of a Pilsener - but not worth the price.

A really good Pilsener. Nice golden pour with a creamy white head. Hops just all over the aroma. Chewy taste, some malt, but mostly hops in this one. Quite impressed about this beer from Rogue. Bought this bottle at Whole Foods in Vienna, VA.

Be very careful with this one!  I had already sucked one down when the bartender told me this was an 8.8%  Everything was well balanced and provided a tasty pisner.  A nice sweet hoppy taste with a slightly bitter finish

Dark yellow with a substantial white puff head. Faint Pils hop aroma, clean and proper, but I expected more here. The flavor was well balanced. Slightly sweet with just enough hop bitterness to keep this from straying too far into Helles Bock Country. Pleasant dry mouthfeel and and alcoholic warming that soon follows the first half a glass.

Murky golden yellow pour, with a fast dying white foamy head.  Sweet malty aroma with an underlying fruityness.  Nice malt body. The title "Imperial" definitely fits.  Flavors are sweet upfront with a nice balanced finish.  Smooth mouthfeel with a slighty warming sensation.  Good brew, but loose the cool bottle and make it more affordable.

I was intrigued with the concept of an "Imperial Pilsner". Sorry guys it did not work. Too sweet and no crispness that a true pilsner requires. I see these high ratings an I believe you are letting the Rogue name influence. Great bottle, wish the brew was more outstanding

Interesting beer. It's rich, clean, and smooth. It has all the characteristics of a pils, yet departs from the style early on to become something unique. bitter, malty, hoppy, yet balanced and delicious. A gem of a beer, and an outstanding re-definition of the pils style. Reminds me of a rich, sweet Prima Pils. Recommended.

On Tap: Clear straw hue with a small fuffy white head and some lace. The aroma hints of piney and floral hops, buttery biscuit, grassy notes, and light malty tones. The taste starts with good balance but the hops became more aggressive as I drank, but never did overpower. Some yeasty character and lingering bitterness upon the finish. Lively, crisp mouthfeel. A damn good pilsner, recommended.

I feel a little guilty drinking this now, being considerably congested, but spring break is around the corner and I cannot leave this lying around.  Regardless, A nice sized head and a slightly clowded golden color to it.  Flavor has a small bitterness at first, then a clean robust mouthfeel to it.  Fairly sweet aftertaste, kind of grassy, and slighty acidic.  A good pilsner, but I agree, it would be slightly hard to classify this as one.

Hazy gold with a white head.  Starts off intense IPA like bitterness, but mellows out halfway down.   The malts a very clean and lagerish.   This isn't a bad beer, and is nice for a change of pace, but I feel inside this overweight 9.9%er is a really good 5%er struggling to be free.

Lighly hazy deep gold, very nice lasting white head.  Very clean when chilled, but a light DMS creeps in as it warms.  Also a very nice floral hop aroma w/ some underlying maltiness.  Clean of esters from fermentation.  Falvor seems well balanced, but definitely to bitter, slightly harsh and not rounded for pils style.  Lightly spicey yeast bite/flavor, also some herbal hop, although it seems to have a grassy hop aftertaste.  Still no esters from fermentation.  Low carbonation, fuller bodied, alcohol warming but well hidden and dry m/f.  Although not "true" to a pils style, this is a very good, drinkable beer.  Slight off aromas/flavors take away from it being clean, but still cleaner than a lot of true pils of normal gravity.
golden color with no head.  mildly sweet.  not much like a pilsner at all.  it actually brought to mind a barley wine

Golden, slightly hazy appearance.  Floral, fruity aroma.  After the first sip you'll realize this is not your typical pilsner. A good, hefty body with a balanced sweet malt and hop taste.  Dry, bitter finish.
Draft:  Golden color & crystal clear.  Fruity and sweet, with a strong hoppy presence.  Alcoholic and acidic.  Not sure if I'd call this a pilsener, but it was certainly unique.

Pours a yellow/orange hue with a thick, frothy white head.  I couldn't really pick up any aromas other than a slight yeasty/strawy smell.  Flavor is full of flavor on the palate.  Sweet on initial taste and quick dissapearing.  Tastes like pilsner urquell on steroids.

Sampled at the Wayside Tavern in Cumming, GA. Golden color with a moderate head. Flavor was hoppy for the style with a nice malt profile. Suprisingly it had some citrus and caramel present in the flavor. Probably the most complex pilsner I've ever had. A very well balanced beer. The experience surrounding this beer was also wonderful. I toasted in my #500 rating with many other fellow ratebeerians who were also sampling this beer on the Atlanta Pub Crawl.

Pours a deep golden with a quickly dissipating head. Really big bubbles with a pungent if not stale noble hop aroma. Sweet on the tip of the tongue with a bitterness at the back of the throat. Warms as it reaches the stomach. A ligering sweetness prevails making the beer taste less like a pils and more like a helles bock. Very one-dimensional as well. Should have added some light munich and had a lower mash temperature to achieve better attenuation with less residual sweetness. Not bad but I would have expected more from Rogue and from a beer that costs $11 a bottle. JEEZ MAN!

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2004 Er, its in my notes, so I must have tried it. I apparently liked it quite a bit, too. Shame I can't remember. Sampled (very late in the evening) at the Great Atlanta Pub Crawl, 2004. Re-Rate, May 2004. Tried again, this time sober. Old Gold, decent head. Full, oily palate lets you know right off the bat that this is no ordinary pilsner. Spicy aroma, herbal and floral flavors. Big hop flavors in the finish. Very intriguing brew.

On tap at Summits Wayside tavern in Cumming, Ga.  This one was a big hit at the Pub Crawl.  Poured up a hazy yellow color with a nice white head.  Flavor had a good malty presence but the hopos put me in mind of IPA.  Very tingly mouthfeel.  Excellent rogue

Bottled (gorgeous).  Cloudy medium orange, samllish dying head.  Lovely strong, fruity nose -- strikes me as closer to an IPA.  On the tongue, it's heavily malty, sweet all the way through, with a nice grapefruity bitter hop tang at the finish that lasts and lasts.  Absolutely wonderful body.  One of Rogue's best, eminently drinkable, alcohol well-hidden and the hops better integrated than in many of their celebrated flavors.

Well I have to agree with the last guy that this beer is misleading in the sense that it doesn't fit the mold of what he expected as a pilsner. However, it is a far better crafted beer than 2.9 in my humble opinion. I found it to be full in every way - full of rich orangey colour, full of hoppy citrus piney aroma, full of grapefruit and hops and smooth flavour and full of lingering bitterness and alcohol in the finish. Thanks to radiomgb for bringing this one over - and what a bottle!

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2004 I worry about beers like this. It could be considered as just part of the trend among American brewers of beefing up every style imaginable. Pale ales became IPAs. IPAs became IIPAs. Stouts became imperial stouts, and so on. So now pilsner has become imperial pilsner at 8.8% ABV. The twist however, is that American microbrewers have usually started by making the smaller version before taking it to the next level. It was as if they took IPA to its limits and needed to go to the IIPA to get something new from the basic style of hoppy ale. So that leads to my problem: is this just another example of beefing up a style to get something more out of a style that Rogue has already tackled and pushed to its limit? I don't think so. It seems as if they've skipped the basic pilsner and went straight to the IP - and that's what bothers me. The implication being that pilsner in and of itself is a style not worthy of tackling, and they are starting on the premise that for it to be worthy of their brewing, they have to ratchet it up a few notches. What's wrong with brewing a true session pilsner? So few American breweries do so, and even fewer brew them in adherence to Bohemian traditions, and again even fewer do that successfully enough to produce a pilsner worthy of international admiration. I'm waiting. And just to note, nothing regarding style or expense has biased this rating. It is as the beer is.

In the meantime, this beer has a nice spicy hoppy aroma, with a mild graininess skirting the nose. The malt is full and sweet in the palate, near cloying and grainy. I'd hesitate to pronounce any 3P fruitiness (peach, pear, persimmon) but I'd equally hesitate to declare this as clean. Spicy, almost grassy hop flavors are present in moderation. The finish has a fair bitterness but could stand a bit more IBU to balance the strong malts. Honestly it drinks like the best malt liquor I've ever had rather than any pilsner I've tasted, especially given its strong sweet, nearly grainy malt component and obvious alcoholic kick. The further I get into this big bottle, the more malt liquorish it gets, especially in the sense that the sweetish malts become near overbearing and the alcohol really begins to show up. Appearance is an orange-tinted gold, with a full and thick, near-creamy head that lasts long enough. Lacing is moderate and widely spaced. At final pour, I discovered this is bottle conditioned, yielding a more cloudy yellowish white-gold color. The yeast in the glass smoothed out the flavor quite remarkably. A bottle-conditioned malt liquor! And at $12 for the bottle - the Sam Adams Chocolate Bock is by far the better bargain!

Hazy orange/pineapple in colour.  Aroma was piny, lots of hops and citrus, also pick up on some sourness.  Flavour had some grapefruit, tons of hops and a sugary sweetness.  Finish is a long powerful bitterness.  Thanks jeffc666.

A cloudy, orangish gold liquid. Even though I poured vigorously from this tall, ceramic white bottle, very little head was produced.

Nose is hops, right away, with note of lingering lemon and a solvent like aroma.

Whoa! I thought this was going to be way bitter and alcohol warming, but it is very balanced. Bitterness is there, but malt backbone is there all the way. A little tart on the finish. This is really good, and although 8.8 ABV, you couldn't tell. I wanted another right away.

My first Imperial Pils. Really good. John Maier does it again.

Pours a clear golden yellow with a thin white head.  Mild dry grainy aroma with some European hoppiness.  Starts syrupy sweet and bitter with a piney hop resin flavor and a crisp, clean, dry sweet pilsener/lager type finish.  Gets much better and smoother as it warms.  Hides its alcohol well and combines an almost imperial IPA-like character to a well balanced lager.  A nice and unique brew.

I really expected to be more impressed with this pilsener than I was.  Pours a hazy golden color with a big fizzy head.  Nicely balanced with a bold malt character and some light hoppy sweetness, but something was missing.  Very one dimensional, with a big alchohol bite throughout.

26 oz. bottle.   Poured a cloudy yellow color with a nice sized head with large bubbles.  This had a very hoppy taste with a lot of malt flavor in the background.  The finish was very hoppy, not unlike an IPA.  I saw the post by Buck_Dich which says he paid only $5.  My bottle cost $20 + 8% sales tax.  Either I was overcharged or Buck_Dich got a GREAT deal!  It was a good beer, but I won't buy it again for $20 a bottle.

Pours gold, slightly cloudy. Foamy head, some lacing.  Hmm, hops, both floral and citrus in the nose. Malts coming up strong, yet blending in rather well. Just a tad of alcohol. Heavy malts in the flavors, again accompanied by the hops. Though more bitter in this encounter. Big finish of alcohol on this one. The entirity of the beer is shadowed with a "bready" flavor if you will. Pilsener characteristics come and go throughout Definately makes for an interesting beer though. I like it. Two thumbs up!

Hazy (chewy) straw gold color, whispy even, almost like a wheat. The head is thick and creamy with nice retentiveness and lacing. The aroma hits very strong with a bite of floral and spicy citrus hops and a delicious pils-malt backbone that finishes with a lick of alcohol for good measure, almost like an IPA here. The flavor is intense but so good, lots of hops here to balance the alcohol that wavers in and out. The finish is strong in the alcohol department but the flavors are still the forestage here. Picked this up for $5 at a local store, so I can't complain about this wonderful little/big beer. The more you drink the more adapted you get to the hoppy flavor but the alcohol still hits strong. One of these bottles packs a good punch, I'm definately feeling it after this one.

Viscous golden body with luscious foamy snow white head and wispy streams of carbonation.  Nice aroma of grass, citrus, and light caramel malt.  Rich, full flavor.  It's exactly what you expect it to be... a nice, big pilsner.  Has distinct Czech qualities anyway.  Takes some getting used to but becomes very enjoyable.  Scores points for being so novel.  Another fine effort by Rogue.  I recommend serving this fairly cool.  I tasted it at variable temperatures, but for some reason I preferred it on the cooler side.  That way it was refreshing like a pilsner should be but the big, bold notes still came through very nicely.Either through happenstance or perhaps a subliminal message, I immediately bought some sushi after purchasing this beer.  The connection (Morimoto) didn't occur to me until later.  The pairing was terrific.

Extreme Beer Fest 2004: Hazy light yellow with a small white head.  Orange/grapefruit aroma with some flowers in the aroma.  Full Oily texture, starts sweet and ends sweeter.  Poured by the one and only VENOM.

Extreme Beer Fest '04, Golden in color with a thick white head.Hoppy and malty aroma that's quite clean,no esters(obviously if it's a lager).Flavor is hoppy,alcohol warming and a touch of breadiness from the malt.

Poured out of a very cool bottle that is white ceramic with Japanese lettering and bright swathes of color and as a bonus comes with a swing-top. The beer pours very thick given the golden body. The viscosity makes seem like a pale Imperial Stout. The head is pure white and really sticks to the sides of the glass. The aroma is lots of orange citrus and a very clean and crisp malt aroma. The flavor is citrus up front then a shocking smack of bitter hops followed by a nice biscuity maltiness. The finish is quite bitter, those 74 IBUs really stand out given the relative lightness of this beer (compared to other 74 IBU beers). There is a slight hit of alcohol towards the beginning of the finish but it is not an unpleasant flavor. Given the style the 8.8% ABV is well hidden. Overall a nice beer but it exhibits a lot of ale characteristics and it is hard to believe that this is a lager. A must try, but true lager fans may be disappointed.

I like this one, not near as sweet as Prescription pils, and not as hoppy.  Looks like a classic pils, golden, translusent, and with a moderate white head.  Dry and crisp, but not as dry and crisp as Victory's Prima, after drinking it, it was apparent to me that it was much bigger than Prima.  I know its hard to make a big pils and one that is close to style, I think Rogue accomplished both.

Hazy golden.  Lemon and orange rind aroma.  Light and amazingly clean on the tongue.  Definitley bitter, not a ton of hop flavor, but acceptable.  Fun fresh and fruity.  Doesn't show a trace of the 8.8% alcohol.  Not the worlds most elegant beer, but very very fun, and worth the experience.  I

Great painted ceramic bottle that was capped yet has a swing top attached as well. Poured a slightly hazy bright gold with a huge head that settled down to a not so huge head. Aroma reminds me of a Wit style with wheat malt and yeast in the nose. Maybe it's my imagination though. Also detect quite a bit of hops in the aroma and sweetness from the malt as well. This aroma is a big and bold one to be sure. I wasn't sure what an Imperial Pilsner would be like, but now it makes sense to me with the latest trend in super charged styles. Just double up on malt and hops and you've got an Imperial-fill in the blank brew. Body is really full and smooth. Flavor is also a strong one with sweet malt leading the way along with some hops blending in. This is a big beer and if you like big bold beers such as the Imperial class, you will like this one for sure. It's not a to style pils and doesn't claim to be one either. Enjoy it for what it is.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 3, 2004 The bottle poured with a glug glug sound until I poured about half the bottle out. Anyways, the head is nice and thick and the nose is restrained. The palate is where the hops are to be found. The hops are very earthy and the palate is full and sweet, but not cloying. The finish is long rounded and a little alcoholic. One major flaw I find in the beer is a bit of diacetyl, which is a bummer. Overall, I really do not find this beer to be like a pils.

11/12/03.  Poured out of what I think was a 16.9 oz. white ceramic bottle, enjoyed in a tasting at Hi-Time Wine Cellars in Costa Mesa, CA 11/12/03.  Frothy, small white head.  Hazy gold-yellow body.  Aroma is grassy, earthy, yeasty, and pale malt.  Very crisp.  Flavor of strong bitter hops, lightly yeasty.  Some surprising dirty malt and a strong alcohol undertone.  A little shocking to the palate with the harshness there, but then the finish is rather quick.  It's still harsh but overall a pretty nice beer, and definitely one of the deeper, better pilseners I've had.  I totally agree with the IPA (or even Imperial IPA) comparisons, but I guess that's what you get from an Imperial Pilsener.

At first it has a large frothy lush head, but that fades down pretty quickly.  Cloudy, dark yellow body.  Smells sweet, but not overly sticky.  The flavor is very full for a pilsner, and quite honestly, I'd like pilsners a lot more if they were more like this.

I'm not entirely sure it's fair to classify this beer as a pilsner - pours golden with an impressive white head - the aroma is quite malty sweet, with a small dose of hops and grain, much like an Imperial IPA or a hoppy barleywine - initially, the flavor is clean, crisp and very pilsner-ish, but this is soon demolished by a tongue-slamming of sweet, malty, bready flavors, followed by a healthy helping of hops - the beer attempts a clean, pilsner-like finish, but instead leaves a buttery, hoppy flavor, with some candy-like notes - this is more like an IIPA-barleywine-pilsner-american strong ale conflation of a beer - unique and tasty stuff.

Smells o fhops and hay. Appearance is golden yellow. Flavor dominated by vegetables and hops. Palate is average. Awesome bottle! Had this one at the Southern Ratebeer Gathering in Austin, TX on December 6, 2003.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2004 Brilliant bottle!  Hoppy citric flavor suggesting barleywine, IPA, and British Summer ale in complexion.  Surprisingly quick finish and a lingering light bitter touch. Doesn't add up to much, despite its interest.(Sampled at Southern Ratebeer Gathering, Austin, TX, December 6, 2003) (6-5-7-3-14) // Re-sampled, 20 Aug 04: perhaps my rating could go as high as 3.8 but it was too late in the tasting to trust my judgment, so I'll wait for another taste before re-rating.

Bottle.  Glowing yellow, average head...smells like a very strong and clean pilsner, which is exactly what it is.  Nice!  The taste was very aggressive but didn't reflect the 8.8% ABV at all.  I'd love to give this to BMC drinking friends and tell them "It's the same style as your Bud Light, don't worry..."
Oh, if only I had known there was such a thing as a hoppy pils.  Nice fruity blend.  Mostly apple & pear, and strong citrusy hop flavor.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2004 Frosted cloudy sunflower color. Flowery, tangy aroma that diminished as warmed, nothing impressive. Sweet, slightly sticky finish with not as many hop burps as I'd anticipated. Flavor was too ordinary for the price, unrefined and not complex at all. Straightfoward pilsner amped up with alcohol. Trendy bottle, average beer. Rerate: better on draft than in the fancy-schmancy bottle. Very fresh and rich hops abound. Glad I took another look at it.
Nice bottle, solid white, cool asian markings with a reseal cap.  Come on, is this really a lager?  Very hoppy, some fruity malts, apples.  This beer is defintely one of a kind.

Bottled.
Golden hazy beer with thin white head.
Fruity aroma with herbs, malt and an acidic tone.
Full, alcoholic flavor with peas, yeast and hops. Firm bitterness and extreme maltiness.
Really odd beer. Doesn´t taste anything like a pilsner but still is very  nice. Rogue always surprises. One of coolest bottle designs ever. though.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2013 Soft cloudy yellow appearance.  Spicy wheat aroma, with some sweet citrus as well.  Crisp and hoppy, IPA-like... more so than a pilsner.  Cascade hops are big, and it has creamy mouthfeel but a rough finish.   Very drinkable.
Cloudy gold in color with a whispy head. Citrusy and slightly hoppy aroma.  Strong citrus attack with a broad hoppyness that evaporates quickly.

Hazy pale gold. Sticky, white lacy ring of foam. Earthy, coarse hop nose with powdery, doughy pale malts, orange peel, and solvent. Hints of lemon, honey, and herbs. Notably meaty, musty, and vegetal and far less clean than it needs to be. Soft body with scant tiny bubbles. Fruity and sugary on first sip with notable hints of minty alcohol trailed by a bracing Sterling hop blitz.  Nearly cloying at times. Massive sweetness is momentarily tempered by the astounding hop bitterness. Finishes with a lemon zest, dried apricot, musty pilsner malt collaboration. Lingers with bready pilsner malts and numbing hop sensations. I was hoping for more juicy Sterlings in both the aroma and flavor, more perfume, and lots more dryness and effervescence to define the walloping bitterness. On a brighter note, this will certainly fulfill an evening hop fix.

text: Bottled. Golden coloured. Fruity nose with a hint of acidity. Deep rounded malt profile. Very sweet with a hoppiness that grows towards a very bitter finish. A fancier take on Polish mocný, but certainly no pilsener.

Gets better as it warms, ala, the high ABV, I guess.  Aroma is rather distant and strawish, not a great charateristic.  Things improve from there.  Appearance is dark golden, initally with a egg white head, but that is gone.  Looks like a strong Belgian in my flute.  Flavor mostly redeems the experience.  Flavor resembles Strong American Ales.  Alcohol is evident as are some nice hop varietals.  This is a good drinking experience, however, the price of admission does not match beer experience.

Small white head, short lived. Hazy gold color. Spicey hop nose with some malt backing it up. Medium body. Bready maltiness with plenty of hops to balance them out. Finish is dry, grapey. Not a bad beer, just overpriced.

Seems like I'm the last of our little group from Summits to enter my rating. Nice deep golden body with some cascading bubbles. The head average size, bright white and lasted a reasonable amount of time. Good lacing. Sweet, slightly grassy aroma, a bit of pine, but mostly noble hop aromas. Sandy malt flavor, but not dry. Easy drinking given the size of the beer. A little fruit (almost like apricots or peaches.) Tasty, but there's something missing almost.

Draft-Summit's Wayside Tavern, Cumming, Georgia. Unlike any pilsener I have ever had. I thought it tasted like an I2PA. Massively hopped with a nice white head and great lacing. Aroma is hoppy and citrusy with some pine. Bitter hoppy finish. Nice beer.

(draft) Hazy golden with champagne bubbles and small white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, floral, pine, noble hops, but not especially bitter, plus light bandaid.  Aroma is medium sweet, medium bitter -- pine, some floral.  Medium-full body, very resiny.  Good beer, but seems more an ale than a lager.
Great ceramic bottle.  Earthy honey aroma. Crisp malty flavor with a very bitter finish.  A great Pilsner, but If by Imperial, they mean hops, I sure couldn't tell.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2004 Nothing to distinct in the aroma. The taste is buttery, with herbal hops coming in behind. The alcohol is noticable only as a slight warmth in the taste and a slight fume in the swallow. Very nice buttery taste but it loses the cleanly crispness and palatable spicy hop profile that I look for in a true pilsner. Nice but not worth the price, even with the nice bottle.

I was expecting a bigger gop aroma.  Big ole creamy palate cut short with a striking bitterness.   THe malt flavor is beautiful.  I wish wish also there was more hop flavor.  This beer has real strengths--palate and malt flavor--but as a whole doesnt work all that well.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2003 26 oz. white ceramic bottle, with swing top Grolsch-type ceramic cap & gasket. No freshness date noticed. Poured out a brilliant golden color, with a thick, white, sticky head. Slowly faded back to a sticky lacing on top of the beer & down the sides of the glass.
Aromas right away are of the French Pilsner malts used in brewing this beer. Bready, yeasty, and slightly hoppy tasting. Resinous, piney hops in the middle compete with all the malts, but the malts win out in the end. No alcohol tastes that I can detect. Leaves malty burps in it's wake. Too bad it costs $13 USD a bottle.
More's the pity, too.
What a beer should look like, crisp clear nice head!! Not my favorite style but my favorite of the style! The high ABV diffently add's to the beer. Worth the cost? The bottles nice!

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2003 Poured a golden color with bubbly white head and some lacing.Hoppy caramel aroma followed by citrus fruits.  Taste of honey, banana, grapefruit, hops, bread, phenols and alcohol.  I think this could be aged some.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2003 Hazy yellow beer with a slight head. Floral aroma, with noticable alcohol. Thin malt flavor dominated by hops and alcohol. This beer is over attenuated. Needs some sweetness to balance the hops. The 26 ounce bottle at 13 bucks is nothing more than a novelty and a waste of time. This is only a one dimentional beer for alcoholics.

text:
Slightly hazy yellow lager. Starts with a huge, frothy, white  head. Dimishes to a very small, lasting,  creamy head.
The nose is floral and peppery. Jalapeno, grapefruit peel, buttterscotch and caramel notes.
The flavor is very malty, but remarkably well-balanced.
Up front,the malt is very heavy with notes of butterscotch, caramel and toffee. Nicely bittered.
Full-bodied with a heavy, silky mouthfeel and medium carbonation.  Long, bitter finish. A great pils!

Pretty cool ceramic bottle. Hazy orange color was inviting. Texture was kind of light AND heavy at the same time ... malts were syrupy but the carbonation washed it down. Malts were slightly sweet and lightly toasted, with notes of fresh grains and wheat. Sterling hops were sharp, zingy and spicy; bitterness creeped up, grabbed ahold, and wouldn't let go. Some alcohol notes, especially from the last pour, bottom of the bottle. Juicy notes here and there, too (lemon, orange, and white grapes). Finished dry and clean. Lingering bitterness.

Nice medium gold, big head that slowly fades into a medium lasting head.  Over the top Morimoto bottling.  Big nose of hops, very nice.  Just a blast of pure pilsener hops (Sterling according to the bottle).  Medium body, just enough malt depth and sweetness to stand up to the hops.  A tiny bit earthy, but overall just a true hop flavor.  I'm always impressed by a good pilsener, because it is a style that highlights flaws like nothing else.  Rogue pulled off one good beer here.

Got this in the signature bottle and definitely paid the price for the signature bottle. The beer was the best Pilsner I've had. I tend to like stronger beers so that might explain it. Well made, clean, good hop crispness; I liked it.

Bottle: I don't like pilsners. Nose, Yeasty bisquick. Tart apple, lemon. Lite golden color, fairly clean. Can taste the ABV.  Toasted malt. Hop crispiness. Bitter creamy syrup on the finish. Give you a little pucker. Overall I'm not wild about it. Though it is well made.

text: UPDATED: JAN 25, 2006 1pt10oz bottle. Capped with a swing top attached. Slightly hazy,light,copper. Fizzy,small,but lasting head. Aroma is bready,hay,sweet, floral hops,and touch of spicy alcohol. Not the most pleasing aroma. Soft carbonation, medium body, good texture. Starts rough,but soon becomes very creamy.Flavor starts quite malty,although sticky,floral notes fill the mouth. Alcohol is slightly noticeable in the flavor before finish. Finish is malty,with huge flowery,hop notes. Just the slightest alcohol is noticeable among the floral notes.  Last pour makes beer twice as cloudy. Tons of liquidy,sediment. Thanks  Murph!

Poured only about half of the ceramic crock into a glass and sealed the rest for later. Golden blond body with a medium head. Nose is hoppy and crisp but with some malt. Very nice hoppy taste. Not too bitter on the palate but reminds me of a good West Coast IPA. Enough malt in the body to balance this out. Rather creamy finish with a little bit of hop bite towards the end. Great beer!

tiny, slow rising bubbles, soft white head, dissipated quickly.  sweet, pale, floral and alcoholic.  light bodied, but full of citrus and resinous hop tones.  crisp, clean and light.  still a pilsner, but a mighty fine one at that.
stringent citrus aroma, cloudy yellow with a quickly dissipating head, super light, solid dry/bitter hoppiness dominates

Not your father's pilsner.A little cloudy in color. Creamy head with good retention.Hop & malt character make this a really big but not an IPA style Pils. It is crisp-just big& crisp.Imperial pilsner describes it well.

Didn't buy this, but managed to weasel my way into a free sample. Some good stuff. Great fluffy head. Nothing special in the color. Good body, no stinky, and a healthy lager taste. Could be a fine session beer. Rogue, how I love you!!

Bottled(beautifully!) version. Dusty, thick looking gold juice with a fabulous bready aroma with tropical fruit blossom notes, not strong but nice and persistant. Viscous watermelon pulp mouthfeel with tannins and noble bitterness clamping down a couple of bites up from the tail. Rogue's best ever for this guy.

Had this guy in a nice little visit to the brewery in Newport.  If you ask me, this is what I'll look for in the future out of a pilsner.  It has the basic pilsner flavor, yet this one actually has a back bone.  Very smooth, hides the alcohol.  Probably good it\'s one of those pub only brews (except for the cool limited edition bottles, but i'm not sure how far out those get), because this is the kind of beer that could sneak up on someone.
Sampled at Stone 7th celebration. Cloudy gold, healthy white head. Very unique, a really strong pils with +hops and  actual flavor. Would like some more.

On draft at Stone 7th Anniversary Party.  After standing in line for 10 - 15 minutes at the Rogue booth, I found out that all they had to pour by then was a pils - not usually my favorite. The guy said it was an Imperial Pilsner so what the heck...  Hazy yellow color with a nice white head.  Malty, malty aroma with floral hops.  Flavor is good!  Sweet and malty more ale like character, rich and full with lots of hops and noticible alcohol. Full body, moderate carbonation and drinkable. Nice unique brew and my favorite pils.

I had this on draft at Stone's 7th anniversary party.
Appearance: It's cloudy orange/yellow colored with a modest head.
Flavor: It feels thick and buttery on the tongue. It has a hoppy taste with some maltiness thrown in.
All in all, it's quite nice

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2003 Now, I must admit that I drank this beer out of the brightening tank right before it was to be bottled, but man, what a great beer- very heady. The alcohol is very evident and the saaz will kick your ass. Definitely a palate destroyer.
Tap at the Archer: Opaque amber. Fresh hop nose. Light malt flavor with massive hops. Great body. Good but not in the traditional style
Had this beer at a Beer Fest, understand it is available in the bottle? Very hoppy, very robust, decent malt and hop floral nose.
